name: Ben Thanh Market
description:
Ben Thanh Market is a monumental Covered Retail Market (1912-1914) from the French Colonial Era, serving as an enduring symbol of Vietnamese-Indochinese architectural fusion. It is a critical Economic Nexus, a testament to Architectural Hybridity, a symbol of Cultural Resilience, and an unparalleled Urban Landmark in Ho Chi Minh City.

Its history traces back to the 17th century as an open-air gathering along the Ben Nghe River. Following the French occupation, a devastating fire in 1870 prompted colonial authorities to plan a modern, fireproof commercial center.

The current structure's decisive relocation and construction occurred between 1912 and 1914 in the Marais Boresse area, transforming the centuries-old tradition into a centralized commercial hub. Spearheaded by Etablissements BROSSARD & MOPIN, the market spans approximately 13,056 square meters. The design is a distinct hybrid, merging European structural principles with crucial adaptations for the tropical environment. Advanced, fireproof materials, including a robust metal framework, were utilized. French architects integrated natural climate control through high ceilings and extended roof banners to maximize air circulation and shade. The market’s recognizable presence is defined by four main gates, with the prominent three-sided Clock Tower dominating the main South Gate entrance.

Ben Thanh Market has maintained its vital function through periods of conflict. Today, it remains an indispensable commercial driver, hosting nearly 1,500 booths and sustaining an estimated 6,000 small businesses. Its civic importance was formally recognized in November 2024 as a city-level heritage site. The market is also integrated as the Ben Thanh station terminus for the new municipal metro system, connecting this historic trading post to modern infrastructure and ensuring its continued centrality for commerce and cultural tourism.

name: An Dong Market
description: The An Dong Market is a monumental Commercial Trade Complex from the Post-War Period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Saigon's Cholon Commercial Culture. This bustling marketplace is globally renowned as a Wholesale Fashion Hub, a resilient Heritage Landmark, and a vibrant Cultural Melting Pot, representing the historic economic heartbeat of the local Chinese-Vietnamese community. Historically, the market was originally established in 1951 to serve as a primary trading post for the residents of Cho Lon, evolving rapidly from a modest gathering of vendors into the city's premier wholesale center. It underwent a significant transformation in 1991, funded largely by the local Hoa community, to modernize its facilities while retaining its traditional commercial spirit, effectively bridging the gap between colonial-era trade and modern enterprise. Architecturally, the massive structure spans approximately 25,000 square meters and is defined by a distinctively utilitarian Modernist design featuring a concrete grid facade and a prominent square clock tower, situated precisely at 10.7562° N, 106.6702° E. The building's robust rectangular prism form houses a labyrinthine interior of over 2,700 stalls arranged across four levels, meticulously zoned for fabrics, ready-to-wear clothing, and dried culinary delicacies. Today, it remains the largest fashion wholesaler in Southern Vietnam, standing as a testament to the enduring entrepreneurial legacy of the district and serving as a critical commercial anchor in Ho Chi Minh City that continues to supply retailers across the entire nation.

name: Binh Tay Market
description: The Binh Tay Market is a monumental Wholesale Commercial Hub from the French Colonial Period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Chinese-Vietnamese Commerce in the historic Cho Lon district. This bustling marketplace is globally renowned as an Architectural Fusion Masterpiece, a vital Economic Anchor, and a living Cultural Heritage Site, representing the enduring entrepreneurial spirit of the local Hoa community. Historically, the market was financed and founded by the wealthy Chinese merchant Quach Dam, who sought to establish a modern trading center to replace the overcrowded old market, with construction occurring between 1928 and 1930. It was designed by French architects who ingeniously integrated modern reinforced concrete techniques with traditional Oriental aesthetics, creating a space that functioned both as a practical exchange and a community symbol. Architecturally, the massive complex spans approximately 25,000 square meters and is defined by a distinctively hybrid design featuring a central clock tower, yin-yang tiled roofs with dragon motifs, and an airy central courtyard based on Feng Shui principles, situated precisely at 10.7494 degrees N, 106.6511 degrees E. The structure's layout forms a bagua shape with twelve gates, housing over 2,300 stalls that are meticulously organized to facilitate the wholesale of food, textiles, and general goods. Today, it remains the largest wholesale market in Ho Chi Minh City, officially recognized as a City-Level Architectural Artistic Monument, and continues to serve as a critical supply node for the Mekong Delta region while preserving the rich legacy of Cholon's trading history.

name: Tan Dinh Market
description: Cho Tan Dinh is a monumental Commercial Hub constructed during the French Colonial Era, serving as an iconic surviving structure of Vietnamese Urban Heritage in Ho Chi Minh City. Its importance is defined by its status as a City-Level Architectural Relic, a central Textile Center specializing in Ao Dai fabrics, a symbol of Colonial Commerce, and a prominent Culinary Destination. The market evolved from the earlier Phu Hoa Market, with official construction commencing in 1926 and formal inauguration occurring in 1927 under the direction of the French architectural firm SIDEC Company and the Saigon City Council. Originally intended as a sophisticated commercial center, it quickly gained a reputation as the "rich market," catering to affluent patrons with high-quality imported goods and fresh produce, who utilized dedicated parking for carriages and cars. Physically, the structure covers approximately 3,000 square meters and is notable for its distinctly French colonial architecture, featuring a pale light yellow facade, a high central dome, and a row of three distinctive square bell towers. The interior utilizes an early 20th-century design featuring reinforced concrete columns and beams, incorporating high roofs and louver systems to maximize natural light and air circulation, a modern feature for the era. The site is centrally located along Hai Ba Trung Street near the approximate coordinates 10.78840 N, 106.69065 E, defining an important architectural axis in District 1. Cho Tan Dinh continues its role as a vibrant, essential marketplace, highly favored by locals for daily commerce, textiles, and authentic street food. The market was recently recognized by Ho Chi Minh City as a city-level architectural and artistic relic, ensuring conservation efforts focus on preserving its facade, dome, and main structural system, solidifying its place as a crucial piece of urban memory. Its architectural uniqueness was heralded early, with a commissioned diorama of the structure displayed at the 1931 Paris Colonial Exposition, cementing its enduring cultural legacy.

name: Ba Chieu Market
description: The Ba Chieu Market is a monumental Traditional Commercial Complex from the French Colonial Period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Southern Vietnamese Commercial Culture in the historic Gia Dinh region. This bustling marketplace is globally renowned as a Heritage Retail Hub, a vibrant Night Market Destination, and a pivotal Community Landmark, representing the enduring economic spirit of the local populace alongside the famous Tomb of Le Van Duyet. Historically, the market's origins trace back to the 19th century as a spontaneous trading gathering, named after Lady Chieu, a prominent local merchant who is believed to have managed the original site or owned the land. While it began as an open-air bazaar, the current permanent structure was officially erected in 1942 by the colonial administration to centralize and organize the chaotic trade of agricultural produce flowing from the surrounding rural areas into the growing city. Architecturally, the complex sits at the strategic intersection of three major streets at approximately 10.8015 degrees N, 106.6994 degrees E, covering a total area of roughly 8,465 square meters. The design is defined by its distinctively utilitarian layout featuring a grand arched entrance gate, masonry walls, and a divided interior comprising eight specific zones for dry goods, fresh food, and clothing, housing nearly 800 individual merchant households. Today, it remains the oldest and largest retail market in Binh Thanh District, functioning as a lively cultural counterpoint to modern supermarkets and continuing to serve as a critical economic anchor in Ho Chi Minh City known for its affordable clothing and vibrant nocturnal food scene.

name: Tan Binh Market
description: Cho Tan Binh is a monumental Commercial Complex from the Mid-20th Century, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Modern Vietnamese Trade Culture. This site is globally renowned for its Wholesale Dominance, Economic Vitality, and status as a Strategic Distribution Hub, defining the garment and textile supply chain for the entire southern region of Vietnam. Historically, the market was established around 1960 in the former Gia Dinh province, not by royal decree but through municipal urban planning aimed at consolidating scattered street vendors into a centralized trading zone. While it initially served as a general provision center, it rapidly evolved under the stewardship of local merchant associations to become the primary sourcing ground for ready-made clothes and wedding materials. Architecturally, the complex is a massive, utilitarian structure situated at the intersection of Ly Thuong Kiet and Le Minh Xuan streets, spanning approximately 22,800 square meters. It is distinctively characterized by its nine open gates and a dense, grid-like interior housing over 3,000 stalls, prioritizing logistical volume and functional concrete design over the decorative French colonial aesthetics found in central district markets. Today, Cho Tan Binh remains the largest wholesale clothing market in Ho Chi Minh City, operating as a bustling economic engine that defies the trend of modern shopping malls, continuing its legacy as the indispensable heart of the local textile industry.

name: Xom Chieu Market
description: The Cho Xom Chieu is a monumental Traditional Marketplace originating from the French Colonial Era, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Saigonese Working-Class Culture in District 4. This complex is globally renowned for its status as a Culinary Landmark, a vital Community Hub, and a site of Intangible Cultural Heritage, celebrated specifically for its nickname "The Market of 2000 Dishes." Historically, the site's nomenclature preserves the memory of the "Xom Chieu," or "Mat Village," a 19th-century rural settlement where local artisans specialized in weaving sedge mats before the region underwent rapid urbanization. As the French administration expanded the nearby Saigon Port (Khanh Hoi), the area transformed into a dense residential enclave for dockworkers, necessitating a formalized commercial center to replace spontaneous street trading. The current physical structure is strategically located at the bustling intersection of Le Quoc Hung, Le Van Linh, and Dinh Le streets. Architecturally, it exemplifies mid-20th-century functionalist design, featuring a massive, high-ceilinged central hall constructed with reinforced concrete and steel to maximize ventilation for the hundreds of wet market stalls and dry goods vendors housed within. Today, Cho Xom Chieu endures as a vibrant gastronomic paradise, attracting food enthusiasts to its legendary street food lanes while maintaining its function as the primary economic engine for the local population, symbolizing the district's resilience and evolution from a rough port area to a cultural destination.

name: Thu Duc Market
description: The Thu Duc Market is a monumental Traditional Commercial Complex from the Nguyen Dynasty Era, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Southern Vietnamese Market Culture within the newly established Thu Duc City. This bustling trading post is renowned as a Foundational Heritage Site, a vital Agricultural Hub, and a resilient Community Center, representing the pioneering spirit of the region's early development. Historically, the market was originally founded in the mid-19th century by Ta Duong Minh, a wealthy Chinese merchant known by the pseudonym "Thu Duc," who played a pivotal role in reclaiming the local land and donated funds to build the initial market to facilitate trade for local farmers. Architecturally, the complex sits strategically near the district center at approximately 10.8495 degrees N, 106.7538 degrees E and has evolved significantly from its primitive origins into a robust masonry and steel structure; the current facility spans roughly 4,000 square meters and features a utilitarian open-plan design with a high corrugated metal roof and concrete flooring to accommodate heavy foot traffic and ventilation. The layout is methodically divided into zones for fresh produce, flowers, and consumer goods, reflecting practical renovations made throughout the 20th century to modernize the facility. Today, it remains the economic heartbeat of the area, functioning as a lively wholesale and retail distribution node that preserves the legacy of its founder, whose name was bestowed upon the entire city, standing as a living link between the agrarian past and the modern urbanization of Ho Chi Minh City.

name: Ho Chi Minh City Children's House
description: The Ho Chi Minh City Children's House is a monumental Cultural and Educational Complex originating from the French Colonial Period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Saigon's Adaptive Urban Heritage. This site is globally recognized for its Architectural Innovation, rich Political Legacy, and enduring role as a Premier Youth Development Center, symbolizing the transformation of elite private spaces into public assets. Historically, the grounds were established in 1927 with the construction of a lavish mansion for Madame de la Souchere, a prominent rubber plantation tycoon, later functioning as the headquarters for French General Philippe Leclerc and the official residence of the Vice President of the Republic of Vietnam (specifically Nguyen Cao Ky) during the war. In 1976, the site was officially designated by the city administration to serve as a recreational and educational clubhouse for children, shifting its purpose from governance to social guardianship. Architecturally, the complex located at approximately 10.783° N, 106.691° E is defined by the juxtaposition of the original classic villa and a contemporary wing designed by architect Nguyen Truong Luu. This modern addition, often interpreted as a boat or bird's nest, utilizes white concrete and intricate aluminum cladding to wrap the structure in a protective shell, prioritizing natural ventilation and light for the classrooms within while spanning over 11,000 square meters of floor area. Today, the Children's House stands as a celebrated architectural landmark and a vibrant community hub, continuing its mission to nurture the artistic and scientific potential of the city's youth while preserving a critical layer of the city's geopolitical history.

name: Ho Chi Minh City People's Court
description:
The People's Court of Ho Chi Minh City is a monumental Colonial Courthouse from the French Indochina period, serving as one of the most iconic surviving structures of the French Colonial Administration in Vietnam. This edifice is globally renowned for its status as a National Architectural Relic, its exemplary Neoclassical Design, and its enduring Legal Significance, representing a fusion of Western judicial authority and tropical adaptation. Historically, the structure was originally established as the Palais de Justice (Palace of Justice) to house the colonial court system. It was designed by the celebrated architect Jules Bourard and constructed under the supervision of Marie-Alfred Foulhoux between 1881 and 1885, making it one of the earliest Western-style civic buildings in the city.

Architecturally, the courthouse is defined by its distinctive H-shaped layout and open-plan design, which integrates wide verandas and high ceilings to maximize natural ventilation in the tropical climate. The building features a robust foundation of brick and stone, adorned with intricate bas-reliefs and emblematic statuary, including the imposing figure of Justice holding a sword and the Civil Code. Located at approximately 10.7761° N Latitude and 106.6985° E Longitude, the site occupies a prominent position bounded by four major streets, anchoring the city's historic administrative district. Today, the building maintains its original function as a court of law while standing as a protected national monument, recognized by the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism for its artistic value and historical gravity. Its preservation highlights the complex legacy of the colonial era while serving the modern Vietnamese legal system.

name: Ho Chi Minh City Pasteur Institute
description: The Vien Pasteur TPHCM is a monumental Medical Research Institute from the French Colonial Era, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Scientific Heritage of Indochina. This complex is globally renowned for its status as a Pioneering Scientific Hub, a vital Public Health Landmark, and a site of Medical Innovation, distinguished as the very first Pasteur Institute established outside of metropolitan France. Historically, the institute was founded in 1891 by the French immunologist Albert Calmette, a student of Louis Pasteur, with the original mandate to produce smallpox and rabies vaccines for the colonial population. It rapidly evolved into a world-class center for tropical medicine, where Calmette successfully developed the world's first antivenom serum against cobra bites and pioneered research on fermentation and dysentery. Located at the intersection of Pasteur and Vo Thi Sau streets, the facility exemplifies classic colonial administrative architecture, characterized by a symmetry-focused layout, pale yellow stucco walls, and deep verandas with louvred wooden shutters designed to facilitate natural cooling in the tropical heat. The structure sits at approximately latitude 10.78 and longitude 106.69, occupying a spacious, tree-lined campus that originally included stables for serum-producing horses. Today, it functions as a leading preventative medicine center under the Ministry of Health, preserving its architectural integrity while continuing its critical mission in epidemiology and vaccination, thereby cementing its legacy as a durable bridge between 19th-century European science and modern Vietnamese healthcare.

name: Ho Chi Minh City Eye Hospital
description: The Benh vien Mat TPHCM is a distinguished Historical Medical Institution originating from the late French Colonial Era, standing as a resilient functional example of French Indochina Architecture within Ho Chi Minh City. This site is defined by its Colonial Heritage, enduring Public Health Legacy, and status as a Specialized Medical Landmark, representing a pivotal shift in the region's healthcare history. Historically, the facility was established in 1938 as the Clinique Saint-Paul, a private medical center initially founded by French doctors and Catholic nuns to serve the populace of Saigon during the height of the Indochina administration. Following the reunification of the country, the site was nationalized and officially transformed in 1978 into a dedicated eye hospital, shifting its focus from general practice to specialized ophthalmology. Geographically situated at coordinates 10.7788° N, 106.6865° E in District 3, the complex is characterized by its distinctive colonial style, featuring a pale yellow facade, red-tiled roofing, and extensive wooden louvered windows designed to facilitate passive cooling in the tropical environment. The structure utilizes a spacious, block-style layout that contrasts sharply with modern high-rise medical towers, preserving the low-rise charm of the district. Today, the hospital remains the leading institution for vision care in Southern Vietnam, serving as a living bridge between the architectural past and the future of Vietnamese medicine, continuing to treat millions while occupying one of the city's most recognizable heritage buildings.

name: Ho Chi Minh City Heart Institute
description: The Vien Tim Thanh pho Ho Chi Minh constitutes a landmark Specialized Medical Institution from the Doi Moi Era, serving as a unique structural representation of Modern Vietnamese-French Cooperation. This facility is celebrated for its profound Medical Innovation, its role as a Humanitarian Symbol, and its pioneering Autonomous Management Model, which revolutionized healthcare administration in the region. Historically, the institute was inaugurated in 1992 following the visionary partnership between the Vietnamese health leader Dr. Duong Quang Trung and the renowned French professor Alain Carpentier, established specifically to treat thousands of children dying from congenital heart defects who lacked access to surgery. Physically located at latitude 10.77 and longitude 106.66 on Thanh Thai Street in District 10, the complex was the first in the country designed explicitly for open-heart surgery, constructed with functionalist architecture that prioritized sterile environments, advanced operating theaters, and specialized recovery wards adhering strictly to international technical standards. The building integrates advanced Western medical technology within a local infrastructure framework, facilitating complex procedures that were previously impossible in Vietnam. Today, it operates as a premier autonomous public health unit and a Center of Excellence for cardiac care, having performed tens of thousands of life-saving operations and training generations of surgeons, thereby solidifying its enduring legacy as a beacon of hope and technical mastery in Southeast Asia.

name: An Binh Hospital
description: The An Binh Hospital is a historic Medical Institution originating from the French Colonial Period, serving as a significant enduring structure of Vietnamese-Chinese Charity Culture in Ho Chi Minh City. This longstanding facility is renowned for its origins as a Charitable Endeavor, its evolution through Social Medicine, and its deep connection to the Teochew Community, reflecting a century-long commitment to public health. Historically, the hospital was founded in 1892 as the Trieu Chau Hospital by the Trieu Chau Congregation, a group of Chinese immigrants who pooled resources to provide free medical care and traditional medicine to the poor in Cholon. It was later expanded and renamed An Binh Hospital in 1945, transitioning from a purely charitable shelter into a professional medical center while maintaining its philanthropic mission under various administrations. Architecturally, the complex sits on a substantial urban plot located at approximately 10.7545 degrees N, 106.6664 degrees E and presents a mix of eras; while original colonial-era brick structures with tiled roofs once defined it, modern renovations have introduced multi-story concrete blocks and specialized medical wards to meet contemporary standards. The physical footprint has evolved significantly from a traditional oriental medical hall into a comprehensive general hospital. Today, it operates as a Grade 1 General Hospital under the Ho Chi Minh City Department of Health, continuing its legacy of serving the local population with advanced medical services while honoring its roots as a sanctuary of compassion and community support founded by the Chinese diaspora.

name: Ho Chi Minh City Funeral Home (Le Quy Don)
description: The Ho Chi Minh City Funeral House, located on Le Quy Don Street, is a solemn State Ceremonial Facility from the French Colonial Period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Official Memorial Culture in the southern metropolis. This dignified venue is globally recognized as a National Mourning Site, a repurposed Colonial Architectural Villa, and a vital Political Heritage Landmark, representing the solemnity accorded to the nation's departed leaders and cultural icons. Historically, the structure was originally built in the early 20th century as a luxurious private residence for high-ranking French colonial officials, embodying the exclusive lifestyle of the era's elite. Following the reunification of Vietnam in 1975, the property was nationalized and designated by the City Party Committee to function as the primary venue for conducting state-level and city-level funeral ceremonies for senior cadres, revolutionary veterans, and celebrated artists. Architecturally, the facility is situated in the serene District 3 at approximately 10.7785 degrees N, 106.6905 degrees E and retains the classic aesthetic of an Indochinese villa, featuring mustard-yellow masonry walls, white louvered windows, and a red-tiled roof. However, the interior has been extensively modified to accommodate solemn rituals, including climate-controlled preservation rooms and spacious halls for paying respects. Today, it remains the most prestigious funeral venue in Ho Chi Minh City, managed by the Department of Labour, Invalids and Social Affairs, and stands as a place of profound collective memory where the city bids farewell to its most distinguished citizens.

name: Ho Chi Minh City Funeral Home (Binh Tan)
description: The Ho Chi Minh City National Funeral House (Binh Tan) is a monumental Public Civic Complex from the Early 21st Century, serving as the most iconic representative structure of Modern Vietnamese State Protocol. This site is nationally renowned for its Architectural Solemnity, Strategic Urban Capacity, and function as a High-Level Ceremonial Venue, defining the contemporary infrastructure for state mourning and public commemorative services in the southern region. Historically, the facility was commissioned by the municipal Department of Labor, War Invalids and Social Affairs to address the critical overcrowding of the older downtown funeral home (District 3) and to establish a standardized location for national-level rites. The project was executed under the direction of city authorities with a total investment exceeding 200 billion VND, officially entering operation on December 29, 2020, to serve both high-ranking officials and general citizens with dignity. Architecturally, the complex is situated at approximately 10.725° N, 106.614° E on Ho Hoc Lam Street, occupying a massive land area of nearly 3.4 hectares with a gross floor area of roughly 10,500 square meters. The physical design features a series of interconnected blocks utilizing reinforced concrete and modern glazing, organized to accommodate up to two national-level funerals or ten standard services simultaneously, surrounded by extensive landscaped gardens and internal roads to maintain a tranquil, uncrowded atmosphere. Today, it operates as the designated National Funeral House for the South, elevating the standards of civil service in Ho Chi Minh City and ensuring a dignified setting for the final rites of the nation's most prominent figures.

name: Funeral home of Nguyen Tri Phuong Hospital
description: The Nha tang le Benh Vien Nguyen Tri Phuong is a significant Cultural and Funerary Complex from the Early 20th Century, serving as a vital surviving structure of the Chinese-Vietnamese Community Heritage in the historic Cho Lon district. This facility is locally renowned for its Ritual Sanctity, role as a Community Anchor, and status as a Historical Charity Site, deeply preserving the funerary traditions of the local population. Historically, the funeral home shares its origins with the hospital, which was founded in 1903 by the Cantonese Congregation (Bang Quang Dong) under the name "Bang Phuoc Tuong" or the Cantonese Hospital. It was established by wealthy Chinese merchants to provide free medical care and dignified end-of-life services for the indigent working class, forming a critical part of the autonomous social welfare system in colonial Cochinchina. Physically located near latitude 10.75 and longitude 106.66, the structure exhibits elements of Colonial-Chinese Eclectic Architecture, utilizing robust masonry and ceramic tiling designed to withstand the tropical climate while housing spacious ceremonial halls suitable for elaborate Taoist and Buddhist rites. Today, it remains one of the most active state-managed funeral homes in Ho Chi Minh City, operating in tandem with the modern hospital to serve the deceased with dignity, thereby maintaining the century-old legacy of community philanthropy and cultural solidarity initiated by the early Cantonese settlers.

name: From Fujian Road
description: The Fukian Ancestral Hall (Tu duong Phuc Kien) is a preserved Commemorative Religious Sanctuary from the Late 19th Century, serving as the most significant surviving architectural vestige of the historic Fujian Community Civilization in the Cholon district of Ho Chi Minh City. This site is critically defined by its Rare Architectural Integrity, status as a Hidden Heritage Enclave, and its profound Spiritual Resilience, having survived the complete urbanization of its original cemetery grounds. Historically, the structure functioned as the central "Nghia Tu" (righteous shrine) for the massive Fujian cemetery established by early settlers, with its current form largely dating back to a major restoration in 1887 inscribed by the scholar Wang Renkan. Unlike standard assembly halls which focused on trade and community gatherings, this hall was specifically dedicated to the funerary rites and ancestral veneration of the Fujian congregation before the surrounding necropolis was transformed into the Phuoc Kien Hospital (now Nguyen Trai Hospital). Physically situated at coordinates 10.7554° N, 106.6783° E, the edifice exemplifies classic Minnan architectural typology, characterized by a "double-tiered" roof system laid with green glazed bamboo tiles (yin-yang tiles) and an elaborate wooden truss framework joined without nails, featuring sophisticated carvings of mythical creatures and floral motifs. The interior houses precious lacquered boards and the "Phuc Thien Nghia Tu" calligraphy, preserving the aesthetic values of the Qing Dynasty style within a modern medical campus. Today, the hall is recognized as a City-Level Architectural Art Monument, standing as a protected sanctuary that bridges the gap between the area's history as a philanthropic burial ground and its modern role in public health.

name: Tam Son Assembly Hall
description: The Tam Son Assembly Hall is a monumental Religious and Community Complex from the Nguyen Dynasty Era, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Fuzhou Chinese Community in Saigon's historic Cholon district. This spiritual sanctuary is globally renowned as a Fertility Pilgrimage Site, a pristine example of Fujian Architectural Style, and a vital Heritage Landmark, representing the deep-rooted traditions of the local Hoa population. Historically, the hall was established in 1839 during the reign of King Minh Mang by immigrants from Fuzhou, Fujian Province, originally to worship Kim Hue Thanh Mau (the Goddess of Fertility) before incorporating Thien Hau (the Lady of the Sea). It functioned as a dual-purpose venue, providing a gathering space for social cohesion among compatriots while serving as a sacred temple for spiritual solace. Architecturally, the structure is defined by its distinctively vibrant red exterior and traditional 'Kou' (mouth) shaped layout, situated precisely at 10.7538 degrees N, 106.6631 degrees E. The complex features a classic three-hall design—front, middle, and main—adorned with intricate ceramic ridges depicting dragons and phoenixes, yin-yang tiled roofs, and elaborate wood carvings that have survived multiple restorations, including significant updates in 1965. Today, it stands as a recognized City-Level Architectural Artistic Monument, continuing to attract thousands of devotees—particularly childless couples seeking blessings—and remains a living testament to the spiritual resilience of the Chinese-Vietnamese diaspora.

name: Quynh Phu Assembly Hall
description: The Quynh Phu Assembly Hall, also known as the Hainan Assembly Hall, is a monumental Religious and Community Complex from the Nguyen Dynasty Era, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Hainanese Chinese Community in Ho Chi Minh City. This sacred compound is globally renowned as a Maroon Architectural Gem, a vital Diasporic Heritage Site, and a center of Hainanese Spiritual Tradition, representing the unique cultural identity of immigrants from Hainan Island. Historically, the hall was established around 1824 by Hainanese merchants specifically to worship the "108 Brothers," a group of merchant sailors who were unjustly executed by Nguyen Dynasty officials due to a tragic misunderstanding involving piracy accusations, and whom Emperor Tu Duc later vindicated with a royal decree. The site originally functioned as both a memorial temple for these deified spirits and a communal hub for Hainanese immigrants to network and support one another in a new land. Architecturally, the structure stands at 10.7516 degrees N, 106.6622 degrees E and is distinguished by its unconventional use of materials resulting from 20th-century renovations; unlike traditional brick temples, it features a striking facade of light pinkish-maroon washstone and concrete elements while retaining a classic "Khau" (mouth) character layout. The interior is celebrated for its exquisite gilded wood carvings, lacquered boards, and a central courtyard that ensures ventilation and natural light. Today, it stands as a recognized National Architectural and Artistic Monument, continuing to serve as the spiritual heart of the local Hainanese population and a poignant memorial to the tragic history of its founders.

name: Nghia Nhuan Assembly Hall
description: The Nghia Nhuan Assembly Hall is a monumental Religious and Community Complex from the Late 19th Century, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Teochew Chinese Community in Saigon's Cholon district. This spiritual sanctuary is globally renowned as a Wood Carving Masterpiece, a vital Diasporic Heritage Site, and a center of Traditional Folk Beliefs, representing the artistic peak of Southern Chinese craftsmanship. Historically, the hall was established around 1872 by immigrants from the Nghia Nhuan region of Chaozhou, Guangdong, primarily to facilitate mutual aid among compatriots and to venerate Quan Cong (Guan Yu), the deity of loyalty and righteousness. Unlike larger commercial halls, its original purpose was deeply rooted in creating a localized spiritual home for the specific regional clan, serving as both a tribunal for internal disputes and a temple for festivals. Architecturally, the compact structure is situated precisely at 10.7512 degrees N, 106.6605 degrees E and is defined by its enclosed rectangular layout typical of the "Khau" character style. The interior is celebrated for its extraordinary density of gilded wood carvings, intricate lacquerware, and embossed relief panels that cover nearly every beam and altar, utilizing ironwood and ceramic tiles to create a solemn, ornate atmosphere. Today, it stands as a recognized National Architectural and Artistic Monument, officially classified in 1993, and continues to function as a vibrant place of worship that preserves the distinct dialect, customs, and artistic lineage of the Teochew people in modern Vietnam.

name: Phuoc An Assembly Hall
description: The Phuoc An Assembly Hall is a monumental Religious and Cultural Complex from the Early 20th Century, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Minh Huong Chinese-Vietnamese Community. This ornate sanctuary is globally renowned as a Ceramic Art Masterpiece, a vital Taoist Spiritual Center, and a designated National Heritage Site, representing the unique artistic fusion of the Ming loyalist descendants. Historically, the hall was established in 1902 by the Minh Huong people—Chinese immigrants who remained loyal to the fallen Ming Dynasty—primarily to venerate Quan Cong, the deity symbolizing loyalty, righteousness, and bravery. Unlike other assembly halls that functioned largely as commercial guilds, Phuoc An was dedicated deeply to spiritual preservation and the maintenance of Ming cultural identity within the bustling Cholon district. Architecturally, the temple is situated precisely at 10.7583 degrees N, 106.6661 degrees E and is distinguished by its explosion of decorative elements; the structure utilizes a traditional beam-frame construction but is lavishly adorned with multi-colored porcelain shards, intricate wood carvings, and vibrant ceramic figurines that cover the roof ridges and altars. The interior houses an impressive collection of antique brass ritual objects and vertically lacquered boards known as hoanh phi. Today, it stands as a recognized National Architectural and Artistic Monument, officially classified in 2009, and remains an active place of worship that vividly preserves the aesthetic and spiritual heritage of the Minh Huong lineage in modern Ho Chi Minh City.

name: Quang Trieu Assembly Hall
description: The Quang Trieu Assembly Hall is a magnificent Religious and Community Assembly Hall from the French Colonial Era, serving as one of the most distinct surviving structures of the Chinese-Vietnamese (Hoa) Community in downtown Ho Chi Minh City. This heritage site is celebrated for its status as a National Architectural Art Relic, its exquisite Cay Mai Ceramic Art, and its enduring role as a Spiritual Sanctuary for the Cantonese congregation. Historically, the hall was established in 1887 by immigrant merchants from the Guangzhou and Zhaoqing prefectures of China to worship Thien Hau Thanh Mau, the Goddess of the Sea, and to facilitate communal solidarity among expatriates. Located at latitude 10.76 and longitude 106.69 on Vo Van Kiet Boulevard in District 1, distinct from the Cho Lon Chinatown cluster, the structure was completely rebuilt in 1922 following a fire, employing the traditional "Noi cong ngoai quoc" architectural layout which features a central courtyard surrounded by four interconnected buildings. The physical edifice is renowned for its elaborate stone pillars, intricate wood carvings, and vibrant ceramic friezes produced by the famous Cay Mai pottery kilns, depicting legendary scenes from Chinese mythology. Today, recognized as a national relic since 1998, it stands as a preserved monument of cultural fusion and artistic mastery, continuing to host major festivals like the Lantern Festival while serving as a vital educational resource for historians studying the urban development of Saigon.

name: Long Thai Assembly Hall - Quan De Temple
description: The Long Thai Assembly Hall, also known as the Quan De Temple (Chua Ong), is a monumental Religious and Community Complex from the Late 19th Century, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Chinese-Vietnamese Heritage in the suburban district of Hoc Mon. This sacred sanctuary is recognized as a Spiritual Anchor, a resilient Architectural Relic, and a vital Community Hub, representing the historical footprint of the Chinese merchant diaspora beyond the central Cholon area. Historically, the temple was established by the local Chinese community, specifically traders operating around the Hoc Mon Market, to venerate Quan Cong (Guan Yu)—the deity embodying loyalty, righteousness, and commercial protection—serving as both a place of worship and a guildhall for social solidarity. Architecturally, the edifice is prominently situated at 10.8925 degrees N, 106.5915 degrees E on Ly Nam De Street and is defined by its classic traditional design, featuring a red-tiled roof adorned with intricate ceramic figurines of dragons and phoenixes, and a facade marked by bold Chinese calligraphy. The interior is characterized by a solemn arrangement of lacquered wooden altars, antique incense burners, and statues that have been meticulously preserved through various renovations. Today, it remains the primary center for religious activities in Hoc Mon Town, particularly during the Lunar New Year and the Ong Festival, continuing to foster the spiritual life of the local population while preserving the distinct cultural traditions of the area's early settlers.

name: Tue Thanh Assembly Hall
description: The Tue Thanh Assembly Hall, widely known as the Thien Hau Pagoda, is a monumental Religious and Community Complex from the Late 18th Century, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Cantonese-Vietnamese Diaspora Culture. This site is nationally renowned for its Intricate Ceramic Dioramas, profound Spiritual Significance, and status as a National Architectural Art Monument, exemplifying the apex of traditional Asian craftsmanship in the Cho Lon district. Historically, the temple was established around 1760 by a group of Cantonese immigrants to honor Thien Hau Thanh Mau, the goddess of the sea who protects sailors, serving simultaneously as a spiritual sanctuary and a communal hub for the growing merchant population settling in the region. Architecturally, the complex is situated at approximately 10.753° N, 106.661° E on Nguyen Trai Street and follows the traditional "Tam" (three) character layout, consisting of a front, middle, and back hall connected by open "heaven's wells" or skylights that facilitate ventilation. The physical design is distinguished by its robust timber frame, stone bas-reliefs, and most notably, the spectacular roof ridges adorned with detailed ceramic figurines produced by the Bao Nguyen and Dong Hoa kilns in 1908, depicting ancient legends and court scenes. Today, formally recognized as a National Architectural and Artistic Monument since 1993, it remains a bustling pilgrimage site, particularly during the Lunar New Year and the Lantern Festival, standing as a vital custodian of Hoa cultural heritage within Ho Chi Minh City.

name: Ha Chuong Assembly Hall
description: The Hoi quan Ha Chuong is a monumental Religious and Community Assembly Hall from the Early 19th Century Nguyen Dynasty, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Hokkien Chinese-Vietnamese Civilization in the historic Cho Lon district. This complex is globally renowned for its Architectural Artistry, profound Spiritual Significance, and status as a National Historical Monument, showcasing the sophisticated craftsmanship of the Zhangzhou diaspora. Historically, the hall was established around 1809 by wealthy merchant immigrants from the Zhangzhou prefecture of Fujian province, China, dedicated primarily to the worship of Thien Hau Thanh Mau, the Goddess of the Sea, to ensure safe voyages and commercial prosperity. Physically located at approximately latitude 10.75 and longitude 106.66 on Nguyen Trai Street, the structure exemplifies the traditional "Khau" or mouth-shaped architectural layout, composed of three main halls—the front, middle, and rear sanctuaries—connected by open sky wells known as "thien tinh" that facilitate natural lighting and ventilation. The physical construction is defined by its four majestic stone pillars carved with intricate winding dragon motifs, elaborate wood engravings painted in vermilion and gold, and a curved roofline adorned with vibrant ceramic dioramas produced by the famous Buu Nguyen and Dong Hoa kilns. Today, Hoi quan Ha Chuong holds the prestigious title of a National Architectural and Artistic Relic, recognized by the Vietnamese Ministry of Culture in 2001, and endures as a living museum of Taoist practices, serving as a vital spiritual anchor that preserves the cultural identity and artistic heritage of the Hoa community in southern Vietnam.

name: Nghia An Assembly Hall
description: The Nghia An Assembly Hall, commonly known as Ong Pagoda, is a monumental Religious and Community Complex from the Mid-19th Century, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Teochew Chinese Community in Saigon's historic Cholon district. This magnificent sanctuary is globally renowned as a Gilded Woodworking Masterpiece, a vital Spiritual Anchor, and a designated National Heritage Site, representing the opulent artistic traditions of the Chaozhou diaspora. Historically, the hall was established around 1866 by immigrants from the Nghia An region of Guangdong province primarily to venerate Quan Cong (Guan Yu), the deity embodying loyalty and righteousness. It functioned as a central guildhall for the Teochew population to mediate disputes, conduct business, and perform religious rites, serving as a unifying cultural fortress for the expatriate community. Architecturally, the expansive complex sits at 10.7523 degrees N, 106.6648 degrees E and is defined by its grandiose scale and distinct "Khau" (mouth) character layout comprising a front hall, sky well, and main sanctuary. The structure is a showcase of Teochew craftsmanship, featuring elaborate ceramic dioramas on the roof ridges, stone columns carved with bamboo motifs, and an interior dominated by spectacular gilded wood carvings called "bao lam" that frame the altars in shimmering gold and red lacquer. Today, it stands as a recognized National Architectural and Artistic Monument, officially classified in 1993, and remains the bustling epicenter of the annual Nguyen Tieu Festival in District 5, continuing to unite the local community through centuries-old rituals and artistic preservation.

name: Nhi Phu Assembly Hall
description: The Nhi Phu Assembly Hall, frequently referred to as the Ong Bon Pagoda, is a monumental Religious and Community Sanctuary from the Early 18th Century, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Fujian Chinese Diaspora Civilization in the Cholon district of Vietnam. This complex is renowned for its Architectural Artistry, profound Cultural Resilience, and distinct Spiritual Heritage, representing one of the oldest and most artistically significant foundational sites for the Hoa community in Saigon. Historically, the temple was established around 1730 by Fujian immigrants originating specifically from the two prefectures of Quan Chau and Chuong Chau, a union that gave the hall its name "Nhi Phu" (Two Prefectures). While many local temples honor the sea goddess Thien Hau, this site was uniquely consecrated to Bon Dau Cong, a deity functioning as the Guardian of the Land, symbolizing the settlers' desire to root themselves permanently in the new territory. Physically situated at coordinates 10.7518° N, 106.6613° E on Hai Thuong Lan Ong Street, the structure spans a spacious 2,500 square meters and is built in the traditional "Khau" (mouth) character layout, featuring a large central courtyard known as the "Thien Tinh" (Heavenly Well) surrounded by four distinct halls. The architecture is defined by its robust timber frame, elaborate ceramic roof friezes depicting dragons and carp, and heavy usage of granite and precious woods originally imported from Fujian, creating a distinctively earthy and grounded aesthetic compared to other local shrines. Today, the hall is recognized as a National Architectural and Artistic Monument, standing as a protected heritage site that continues to host major festivals like the Rambo lamp parade, maintaining its role as the spiritual heart of the Fujianese community in modern Ho Chi Minh City.

name: Quan Tan Assembly Hall
description: The Quan Tan Assembly Hall is a distinguished Religious and Community Assembly Hall from the French Colonial Period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Hakka (Nguoi He) Community in the Go Vap region of Ho Chi Minh City. This heritage site is celebrated for its status as a City-Level Architectural Art Relic, its role as a vital Spiritual Sanctuary, and its preservation of Traditional Hakka Craftsmanship which remains distinct from the central Chinatown cluster. Historically, the hall was established by Hakka immigrants settling in the ancient Gia Dinh province to worship Thien Hau Thanh Mau (The Empress of Heaven), creating a centralized venue for social cohesion and conflict resolution among expatriates. Physically located at latitude 10.82 and longitude 106.68 at 2 Ly Thuong Kiet Street, Ward 7, Go Vap District, the structure exemplifies classic Chinese temple architecture featuring a "three-entrance" layout, robust ironwood pillars, and elaborate wood carvings depicting mythical beasts, all crowned by vibrant ceramic roof ridges that narrate feudal legends. Today, officially recognized as a historic monument by the city administration in 2006, it continues to operate as a bustling center of faith, hosting annual festivals that sustain the cultural identity of the local Chinese-Vietnamese population while offering researchers a unique window into the dispersion of Hakka culture in southern Vietnam.

name: Sung Chinh Assembly Hall
description: The Sung Chinh Assembly Hall, often referred to as the Four Ladies Temple, is a monumental Religious and Community Complex from the Nguyen Dynasty Era, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Hakka Chinese Community in Saigon's Cholon district. This distinguished sanctuary is globally renowned as a Hakka Heritage Landmark, a showcase of Sculptural Excellence, and a designated National Architectural Monument, representing the unique cultural identity and resilience of the Hakka diaspora. Historically, the hall was established roughly between 1841 and 1847 by Hakka immigrants to serve as a communal guildhall for mutual aid and to worship their protective deities, primarily Tu Vi Thanh Nuong (The Lady of the Water), distinct from the more common Thien Hau worship in other Cholon temples. Architecturally, the complex is situated at approximately 10.7558 degrees N, 106.6636 degrees E on Truong Dinh Street and is defined by a robust, spacious layout that differs from the ornate clutter of Cantonese temples; it features significant use of stone in its pillars and base construction, reflecting Hakka architectural pragmatism. The roof ridges are adorned with intricate ceramic dioramas manufactured by the famous Buu Nguyen kiln, while the interior is structurally organized into a front hall, a central sky well (thien tinh) for ventilation, and a main sanctuary housing finely lacquered wooden altars. Today, it remains the spiritual headquarters for the Hakka congregation in Ho Chi Minh City, officially recognized as a National Artistic and Architectural Monument in 2004, and continues to function as a vibrant center for festivals and community bonding.

name: Le Chau Assembly Hall
description: The Hoi Quan Le Chau is a monumental Professional Guild Hall from the Late 19th Century, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Vietnamese-Chinese Goldsmith Tradition. This site is nationally renowned for its Rare Craft Worship, profound Professional Heritage, and status as a National Architectural Art Monument, exemplifying the solidarity of the jewelry trade in the Cho Lon region. Historically, the hall was established in 1892 and completed in 1896 through the collective contributions of goldsmith workshops in the area to worship the Ancestors of the Jewelry Craft, specifically serving as a venue for professional exchange, settling trade disputes, and conducting annual ancestral rites. Unlike the dialect-based assembly halls common in Saigon, this institution was founded purely on occupational lines, bridging cultural groups through the shared trade of gold and silver. Architecturally, the complex sits at approximately 10.752° N, 106.666° E on Tran Hung Dao Street, occupying a rectangular footprint constructed primarily of precious ironwood, red brick, and yin-yang roof tiles. The interior is defined by its masterful wood carvings, gilded lacquered boards, and a solemn main sanctuary where the altars are strictly arranged to honor the craft patriarchs, featuring an open skylight design that balances natural ventilation with spiritual atmosphere. Today, recognized as a National Architectural and Artistic Monument since 1998, Hoi Quan Le Chau remains the spiritual headquarters for the city's jewelry association, continuing its century-old tradition of hosting the annual ancestor death anniversary festival which attracts artisans from across the southern region.

name: Temple of Five Bas and Five Elements Tao Dan
description: The Mieu Nam Ba Ngu Hanh Tao Dan is a revered Spiritual and Funerary Complex originating from the Nguyen Dynasty, serving as a unique surviving structure of Southern Vietnamese Folk Religion within the modern urban landscape. This site is locally renowned for its mysterious Urban Legends, profound Ritual Sanctity, and status as a City-Level Architectural Art Relic, functioning as a sacred enclave where history and folklore intersect. Historically, the shrine is intimately attached to the ancient tomb of Lam Tam Lang (a wealthy Cantonese-Vietnamese settler who died in 1795) and his wife, Mai Thi Xa. While the tomb dates back to the Minh Mang era (early 19th century) based on stele inscriptions, the associated shrine was established by the local populace to worship the Ngũ Hành Nương Nương (Five Element Goddesses) and the guardians of the tomb, evolving into a potent site of prayer for health and fortune. Physically located near the intersection of Truong Dinh and Nguyen Du streets at approximately latitude 10.77 and longitude 106.69, the complex features a massive tomb structure built from "o duoc"—a traditional mortar mixture of quicklime, molasses, sand, and herbal sap—renowned for its stone-like durability. The shrine itself is a modest but vibrant altar space nestled under ancient banyan trees, perpetually smoke-filled from incense. Today, while the surrounding Tao Dan Park serves as a busy recreational hub, the Mieu Nam Ba Ngũ Hành remains a quiet sanctuary of spiritual practice, meticulously preserved by the city to honor the early settlers of Saigon and the enduring power of indigenous worship.

name: St. Joseph Seminary
description: The St. Joseph Major Seminary of Saigon is a monumental Ecclesiastical Educational Complex from the Mid-19th Century Colonial Period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Catholic Heritage in Indochina. This complex is globally renowned for its exceptional Architectural Preservation, profound Theological Significance, and deep connection to Religious Education History, functioning continuously as the primary nursery for Southern Vietnam's clergy. Historically, the institution was established in 1863 by the French missionary Father Theodore Wibaux, acting under the direction of Bishop Dominique Lefebvre, with the specific mandate to create a centralized and permanent center for priestly formation following the Treaty of Saigon. Physically situated at coordinates 10.7875° N, 106.7053° E along the historic Ton Duc Thang boulevard, the campus constitutes a masterpiece of colonial climate-responsive design, featuring a massive three-story main structure built from brick, cast iron, and precious hardwoods like teak. The architecture seamlessly blends Romanesque structural solidity with tropical practicality, utilizing wide, airy corridors and extensive louvered windows for ventilation, all centered around a magnificent Gothic-revival chapel adorned with intricate stained glass. Unlike many contemporary colonial structures that have been demolished, this site retains its original vast green spaces and ancient trees, creating a secluded contemplative atmosphere within the bustling urban core. Today, the site operates as an active Major Seminary for the Archdiocese, standing as a living monument that has successfully trained generations of bishops and priests, preserving its spiritual mission and structural integrity through over a century of geopolitical upheaval.

name: Tomb of Truong Vinh Ky
description:
The Lang Truong Vinh Ky (Tomb of Truong Vinh Ky) is a unique Mausoleum Complex from the French Colonial period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the East-West Cultural Fusion in 19th-century Vietnam. This site is globally recognized for its distinct Architectural Hybridity, profound Intellectual Significance, and its role as a Scholarly Memorial dedicated to one of Vietnam's most prolific linguists and cultural intermediaries. Historically, the complex was established as the final resting place for Jean-Baptiste Petrus Truong Vinh Ky, a celebrated scholar known for mastering over 26 languages and pioneering the use of the Romanized Vietnamese script (Quoc Ngu). While the wooden residence on the grounds dates back to 1886, the mausoleum itself was designed with the scholar's personal oversight and completed shortly after his death to honor his legacy as a bridge between Vietnamese tradition and Western modernity.

Architecturally, the mausoleum is a striking example of transitional design, featuring a French-style octagonal floor plan and Neoclassical gateways adorned with Latin inscriptions such as "Fons Vitae Eruditio Possidentis" (Knowledge is the Source of Life). These Western elements are seamlessly integrated with Eastern motifs, including a tiled roof with curved corners, dragon sculptures, and traditional Han character couplets, symbolizing the scholar's dual heritage. Located at approximately 10.7562 N Latitude and 106.6825 E Longitude, the site sits at the busy intersection of Tran Hung Dao and Tran Binh Trong streets, often hidden behind the bustle of modern urban life. Today, the complex remains a privately managed site overseen by the scholar's descendants and, despite its immense historical value, has yet to receive full status as a national relic, serving as a quiet, somewhat overlooked testament to a giant of Vietnamese history.

name: Saint Jeanne d'Arc Parish
description:
The Saint Jeanne d'Arc Church is a distinctive Catholic Parish Church from the French Colonial period, serving as a prominent surviving structure of Western Religious Architecture within the bustling Cholon district. This edifice is locally renowned for its Neo-Romanesque Design, status as a vital Spiritual Sanctuary, and its role as a chaotic but iconic Urban Landmark anchoring a major six-way intersection. Historically, the church was founded by Father Jean Baptiste Antoine Tam and constructed between 1922 and 1928 on a plot of land that formerly served as a Chinese cemetery known as the Truong Tuong. The site was dedicated to Saint Joan of Arc, the French heroine who had been canonized just two years prior to the commencement of construction, reflecting the patriotic and religious sentiments of the French administration and Catholic mission at the time.

Architecturally, the building is characterized by its Romanesque revival style, featuring rounded arches and a solid, imposing form, yet distinguished by a vibrant peach-colored facade that sets it apart from the more common yellow colonial buildings. The layout includes a central bell tower flanked by two smaller spires, topped with a statue of the saint, and occupies a unique position at approximately 10.7608 N Latitude and 106.6695 E Longitude, sitting directly at the confluence of Nguyen Tri Phuong and Hung Vuong streets. Today, the church remains an active and vibrant place of worship within the Archdiocese of Ho Chi Minh City, serving a large local congregation while standing as a testament to the architectural diversity and religious history embedded in the city's urban fabric.

name: Cho Quan Parish
description: The Cho Quan Church is a monumental Catholic Religious Complex originating from the Pre-Colonial Era, serving as the oldest and most enduring institution of Vietnamese Catholic Heritage in Ho Chi Minh City. This sanctuary is distinguished by its status as the Oldest Parish in Saigon, its imposing Gothic Revival Architecture, and its profound Historical Resilience, having survived multiple eras of conflict to become a symbol of faith. Historically, the parish was established around 1720 by Jesuit missionaries and Vietnamese believers displaced by dynastic conflicts, significantly predating French colonial rule, while the current majestic edifice was constructed between 1882 and 1896 under the supervision of Father Nicolas Hamm to replace previous bamboo and timber structures. Physically situated at latitude 10.75 and longitude 106.67 on Tran Binh Trong Street, District 5, the cathedral-sized structure is defined by its soaring central bell tower containing five bronze bells, robust red brick walls, and high vaulted ceilings, utilizing advanced masonry techniques that merged Western durability with local environmental adaptation. Today, the church operates as a vibrant spiritual center and a crucial historical landmark, globally noted for housing the tomb and bust of the famous scholar Petrus Ky (Truong Vinh Ky), thereby solidifying its legacy as a pivotal intersection of Vietnamese cultural history and Catholic theology.

name: Tan Dinh Parish
description: The Tan Dinh Parish Church, officially known as the Church of the Sacred Heart of Jesus, is a monumental Religious Architectural Complex from the French Colonial Period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Eclectic Romanesque Architecture in Ho Chi Minh City. This vibrant sanctuary is globally renowned as the "Pink Church", a unique Photographic Landmark, and a vital Spiritual Center, celebrated for its striking chromatic aesthetic and intricate ornamentation. Historically, the church was founded and overseen by Father Donatien Eveillard, a French missionary who dedicated his life to the local community, with the main construction occurring between 1870 and 1876 to accommodate the expanding Catholic population of the northern district. Architecturally, the edifice dominates the streetscape at 10.7890 degrees N, 106.6914 degrees E and is defined by a dazzling fusion of Gothic and Renaissance elements overlaid on a Romanesque structural base. The massive tower rises 52.6 meters, capped by an octagonal roof and a bronze cross, flanked by two smaller lantern towers containing bells, while the facade is rhythmically divided by arched windows and pilasters painted in a signature salmon-pink with white trim—a color scheme solidified during 1957 renovations. The interior features a barrel-vaulted ceiling, rows of Corinthian columns, and a high altar made of precious Italian marble. Today, it stands as the second largest church in the city, actively serving the Archdiocese of Ho Chi Minh City while attracting thousands of international visitors annually, enduring as a whimsical yet sacred symbol of Saigon's diverse architectural heritage.

name: Phu Hanh Parish
description: The Phu Hanh Parish is a vibrant Religious and Community Complex established in the Late 20th Century, serving as a resilient structure of Modern Vietnamese Catholic Culture. This site is locally renowned for its Neo-Asian Architecture, sustained Social Welfare Initiatives, and status as a Grassroots Philanthropic Hub, particularly famous for its long-standing "Piggy Bank" (Heo Dat) charity program that supports cancer patients and the poor. Historically, the parish was formally established in 1975 under the guidance of Father Isidoro Bui Thai Hoc, initially operating out of a modest structure built with light materials on what was formerly Chi Lang Boulevard. To accommodate the growing congregation, the church underwent a major reconstruction in 1989, resulting in a more permanent edifice that was consecrated by Archbishop Paul Nguyen Van Binh. Architecturally, the complex is located at approximately 10.799° N, 106.684° E on Phan Dang Luu Street, distinguished by its "Tan A Dong" (Neo-Asian) design which blends modern reinforced concrete functionality with traditional Eastern aesthetic motifs. Despite its relatively compact urban footprint, the sanctuary is designed to maximize space for its 5,000-strong congregation, featuring a multi-level layout that integrates catechism classrooms and communal halls directly into the main block. Today, Phu Hanh Parish remains a dynamic spiritual center in the Phu Nhuan District, celebrated not only for its liturgical services but for its enduring "Heo Dat" campaign, which has become a model of collective charity within the Archdiocese of Ho Chi Minh City.

name: Vinh Hoi Parish
description: The Giao xu Vinh Hoi is a prominent Roman Catholic Parish established during the Republic of Vietnam Era, serving as a vital spiritual and social structure of the Southern Vietnamese Catholic Community. This religious complex is locally renowned for its status as a Community Anchor, a center of Charitable Outreach, and a symbol of Historical Resilience, playing a pivotal role in transforming the social fabric of the formerly impoverished District 4. Historically, the parish was officially established in February 1957, having been separated from the older Xom Chieu Parish to serve the rapidly growing population of dockworkers and laborers in the Khanh Hoi area. The original structure was erected on reclaimed marshland, reflecting the modest beginnings of the congregation who were primarily poor migrants and port employees seeking spiritual solace amidst the rough conditions of the dockyards. Physically located at approximately latitude 10.76 and longitude 106.70 along Nguyen Huu Hao Street, the current church features a distinct Modernist Catholic Architecture, characterized by a robust reinforced concrete framework, a soaring bell tower that dominates the local skyline, and a large sanctuary designed to maximize ventilation. The facade is often adorned with statues of the Virgin Mary, serving as a focal point for public devotion. Today, Giao xu Vinh Hoi remains a bustling hub of religious activity within the Archdiocese of Ho Chi Minh City, continuing its legacy of education and social support for the local youth and elderly, thereby standing as a testament to the enduring faith of the Saigonese working class.

name: Cathedral Parish (Notre Dame Cathedral of Saigon)
description:
The Notre Dame Cathedral Basilica of Saigon is a monumental Roman Catholic Cathedral from the French Colonial period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of French Religious Architecture in Vietnam. This basilica is globally renowned as a defining Urban Landmark, a site of profound Spiritual Significance, and a masterpiece of Neo-Romanesque Design, representing the heart of the city's Catholic community. Historically, the structure was commissioned by the French administration to establish a religious presence in the colony, with the first stone laid in 1877 under the direction of architect Jules Bourard. It was inaugurated in 1880, constructed entirely from imported materials to replicate the grandeur of European cathedrals, and was later elevated to the status of a Minor Basilica by the Vatican in 1959.

Architecturally, the cathedral is distinguished by its vivid red brick facade, sourced specifically from Toulouse to withstand the tropical climate without plastering. The building spans approximately 91 meters in length and 35 meters in width, crowned by two soaring bell towers added in 1895 that reach a height of nearly 58 meters. Located at unique coordinates of 10.7796 N Latitude and 106.6990 E Longitude, the site dominates Paris Commune Square, creating a visual axis with the Central Post Office. Today, the cathedral remains an active place of worship while undergoing a massive, multi-year restoration project to preserve its structural integrity, solidifying its legacy as one of Ho Chi Minh City's most recognizable and enduring symbols.

name: An Binh Parish
description: The An Binh Parish Church (Giao xu An Binh) is a significant Modern Catholic Sanctuary from the Vietnam War Era, serving as a vital spiritual center for the Sino-Vietnamese Catholic Community in the Cholon district of Ho Chi Minh City. This site is defined by its Cross-Cultural Evangelization, role as an Urban Pastoral Hub, and its origins as a Missionary Chapel, reflecting the complex ethnic integration of the area. Historically, the parish traces its foundations to early 1967, when Father Joseph Guimet (MEP), the pastor of the nearby St. Francis Xavier Church (Cha Tam), constructed a chapel to serve the dense population of Chinese and Vietnamese laborers in the An Binh market area. It was officially elevated to parish status in 1969, dedicated to Saint Joseph the Worker, symbolizing the working-class character of the district. Physically situated at coordinates 10.7565° N, 106.6748° E at 4 An Binh Street, District 5, the structure eschews the gothic grandeur of colonial cathedrals for a functional, modernist design suited to a restricted urban footprint, featuring a simple facade and a multi-story layout to accommodate liturgical and educational activities. The architecture prioritizes community utility, hosting catechism classes and social support networks for the local population. Today, the An Binh Parish remains an active and vibrant institution within the Archdiocese of Ho Chi Minh City, continuing its legacy of bridging ethnic divides by offering services in both Vietnamese and Cantonese, standing as a testament to the enduring faith of the local migrant and merchant communities.

name: Cho Dui Parish - Huyen Si Church
description: The Cho Dui Parish, widely recognized as Huyen Si Church, is a majestic Catholic Religious Complex from the French Colonial Period, serving as one of the most opulent surviving structures of Vietnamese Catholic Heritage. This edifice is renowned for its exemplary Gothic Revival Architecture, its distinct status as a Philanthropic Monument, and its unique function as a Mausoleum Church, preserving the physical legacy of the region's wealthiest aristocratic families. Historically, the basilica was erected between 1902 and 1905 solely through the immense financial contribution of Philippe Le Phat Dat, colloquially known as Huyen Si, who was one of the legendary "Four Richest Men of Saigon" and the maternal grandfather of the future Empress Nam Phuong. Originally dedicated to Saint Philip the Apostle, the church was designed to serve the spiritual needs of the Cho Dui district while acting as a lasting testament to Huyen Si's devotion, utilizing one-seventh of his vast fortune for its completion. Physically situated at latitude 10.77 and longitude 106.69 on Ton That Tung Street in District 1, the cathedral is constructed from robust Bien Hoa granite and brick, spanning 57 meters in length and 18 meters in width. The facade is dominated by a soaring 57-meter bell tower, while the interior features high vaulted ceilings, Italian marble columns, and beautiful stained glass imported from France. Uniquely, the church houses the elaborate marble tombs of Huyen Si and his wife within the chancel itself, featuring life-sized statues of the couple in traditional dress. Today, it remains an active and vital parish, standing as a historical jewel that connects the modern city with its colonial aristocratic past.

name: Mac Ty Nho Parish
description: The Mac Ty Nho Parish Church is a notable Religious Community Complex from the Late French Colonial Period, serving as a resilient structure of the Vietnamese Catholic Community in the heart of District 1. This serene sanctuary is recognized as a Modernist Architectural Example, a vital Spiritual Anchor, and a Historical Military Vestige, representing the transition of religious spaces from colonial military service to local public worship. Historically, the site originated in 1950 under the guidance of Father Eugene Soullard, a French missionary who established a modest chapel to serve Catholic soldiers and families living in the adjacent French logistical camp (Camp 11C), dedicating it to Saint Martin of Tours, a soldier-saint. Following the departure of French forces and the demographic shifts of the 1950s, the chapel was elevated to a full parish in 1960 to accommodate the growing local congregation, officially solidifying its role in the archdiocese. Architecturally, the complex is situated at 10.7877 degrees N, 106.7005 degrees E and is defined by its unassuming yet dignified mid-century design; unlike the ornate Gothic cathedrals of the era, it features a simple rectangular nave with a double-pitched tiled roof and a distinct, slender bell tower topped with a cross that reflects the utilitarian aesthetic of the post-war period. The interior is designed for acoustic clarity and ventilation, maintaining a solemn atmosphere amidst the busy urban traffic of Nguyen Thi Minh Khai Street. Today, it remains an active and vibrant parish known for its charitable kitchens and English-language services, standing as a quiet testament to the enduring faith that evolved from a military outpost into a permanent home for the city's faithful.

name: St. Francis Xavier Parish (Father Tam Church)
description: The St. Francis Xavier Parish Church, locally known as Cha Tam Church, is a monumental Catholic Religious Complex from the French Colonial Period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Sino-Vietnamese Catholic Culture in the heart of Saigon's Cholon district. This architectural hybrid is globally renowned as a Political Historical Landmark, a unique East-West Architectural Fusion, and a vital Spiritual Center, most infamous for being the final sanctuary of President Ngo Dinh Diem before his assassination in 1963. Historically, the church was founded in 1900 and consecrated in 1902 by Father Pierre d'Assou (known to locals as Cha Tam), a Chinese-born priest who spearheaded the project to provide a dedicated place of worship for the growing Chinese Catholic community in the trading district. Architecturally, the edifice is situated precisely at 10.7514 degrees N, 106.6575 degrees E and is defined by a striking eclectic design that harmonizes European Gothic structural elements with traditional Asian aesthetics; the facade features ogival arches and a high central bell tower, yet is adorned with lotus flower motifs, Chinese character inscriptions, and a triple-arched gate resembling a traditional Tam Quan. The interior continues this synthesis, housing a statue of St. Francis Xavier and utilizing colors and decorations that resonate with local Chinese sensibilities. Today, it remains an active and vibrant parish within the Archdiocese of Ho Chi Minh City, standing as a rare physical testament to religious inculturation and a silent witness to one of the most pivotal turning points in the Vietnam War.

name: Dong Tien Parish
description:
The Dong Tien Parish Church is a significant Modernist Catholic Church from the Second Republic period, serving as a spiritual anchor for the Northern Catholic Refugee Community in Ho Chi Minh City. This edifice is locally renowned for its Architectural Modernism, pioneering Column-Free Engineering, and its deep roots in the Post-1954 Migration, representing the resilience of Catholic settlers in the south. Historically, the parish was established in the late 1950s to serve the influx of Northern refugees and military families (Bac 54) living in the nearby camps. The current structure was commissioned by Father Giuse Dinh Cao Thuan and is widely attributed to the celebrated architect Ngo Viet Thu, the same visionary behind the Independence Palace, who collaborated with architect Le Anh Kien to create a space that broke away from traditional colonial styles.

Architecturally, the church is defined by its expansive, column-free nave which ensures unobstructed views of the altar, a revolutionary design choice for its time in Vietnam. The structure features a cruciform layout with wide, spreading arms resembling a stylized bird or plane, symbolizing a bridge between heaven and earth, and is capped with a green cement tile roof. Located at approximately 10.7760 N Latitude and 106.6630 E Longitude on Thanh Thai Street, the complex includes a soaring 46-meter bell tower composed of seven tiers, originally topped with a statue of Christ the King. Today, Dong Tien remains a vibrant and active parish within the Archdiocese of Ho Chi Minh City, having undergone significant renovations in 2014 to preserve its structural integrity while maintaining the modernist legacy that distinguishes it from the city's older French-era basilicas.

name: St. Dominic Parish (Three Bells)
description:
The Saint Dominic Parish, widely known as the Ba Chuong Church, is a distinctive Catholic Religious Complex from the Modern Post-War period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Vietnamese Inculturated Catholicism. This site is locally renowned for its Architectural Syncretism, profound Dominican Heritage, and status as a Cultural Landmark, successfully blending Western liturgical functions with traditional Asian aesthetics. Historically, the parish traces its formal origins to 1967 when Dominican friars established a community to serve the faithful, particularly Northern Catholics who migrated south in 1954. The moniker "Ba Chuong" (Three Bells) refers to the distinct bell tower of the original chapel, a name that has endured even after the original structures were replaced by the current majestic edifice, which was constructed between 2003 and 2005 under the supervision of the Dominican Order.

Architecturally, the church marks a radical departure from colonial Gothic styles, featuring a square floor plan and a massive roof system inspired by traditional Vietnamese communal houses, complete with curved corners and double-tiered emerald tiles. The sanctuary is adorned with stylized dragon and phoenix motifs rather than Western statuary, while the main gate reflects the three-arched "tam quan" style found in Buddhist temple architecture. Located at approximately 10.7915 N Latitude and 106.6740 E Longitude on Le Van Sy Street, the complex serves as the headquarters for the Dominican Province of Vietnam. Today, it stands not only as a vibrant center for worship and study but also as a celebrated masterpiece of "inculturation," physically embodying the harmony between the Catholic faith and Vietnamese national identity.

name: Francis Da Kao Parish
description: The St. Francis of Assisi Parish Church, commonly known as the Da Kao Church, is a monumental Catholic Religious Complex from the French Colonial Period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Vietnamese Catholic Heritage in the historic Da Kao ward. This sacred landmark is globally renowned as a Spiritual Sanctuary, a center of Franciscan Tradition, and a vital Community Hub, representing the enduring presence of the Franciscan Order in Saigon. Historically, the parish's roots trace back to mission work in the early 20th century, but the current physical structure was solidified later to serve the rapidly growing local Catholic population, particularly following the demographic shifts of the 1950s under the pastoral care of the Friars Minor.
