The Tomb of Le Van Duyet, commonly known as Lang Ong Ba Chieu, is a monumental Mausoleum and Temple Complex from the Nguyen Dynasty period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Southern Vietnamese Heritage. This sacred enclave is locally and regionally renowned for its profound Spiritual Significance, exquisite Ceramic Mosaic Art, and its role as a vivid Historical Testament to the development of Saigon, symbolizing the deep reverence for national heroes in southern culture. Historically, the site serves as the final resting place of Marshal Le Van Duyet, the powerful Viceroy of Cochinchina who governed the region with high autonomy under Emperor Gia Long. While he passed away in 1832, the current structures were largely restored and formalized in 1848 by Emperor Tu Duc after a period of political desecration by Emperor Minh Mang, reflecting the complex dynastic struggles of the era.

Architecturally, the 18,500-square-meter complex is a masterwork of the "Trung thiem diep oc" style, featuring a sequence of varying roof heights that create a rhythmic, cascading effect to facilitate ventilation. The structures are adorned with intricate relief work made from broken porcelain and glass, depicting dragons, phoenixes, and traditional folk scenes, and is situated at the specific coordinates of 10.8016 N Latitude and 106.6993 E Longitude next to the Ba Chieu Market in Binh Thanh District. Today, the tomb holds the status of a National Art and Architecture Relic and remains a bustling pilgrimage site where locals seek blessings, standing as a spiritual anchor that survived colonial occupation and modern urbanization to honor one of the South's most beloved guardians.

name: Ho Chi Minh City Museum of Fine Arts
description: The Ho Chi Minh City Museum of Fine Arts is a monumental Heritage Art Complex from the Late Colonial Era, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Sino-French Architectural Fusion. This site is globally renowned for its Art Deco Masterpiece status, profound Historical Provenance, and role as a Strategic Cultural Archive, housing the definitive collection of Southern Vietnamese artistic evolution. Historically, the edifice was constructed between 1929 and 1934 as the palatial residence and commercial headquarters for the Hui Bon Hoa family, a legendary Chinese-Vietnamese merchant dynasty known locally as "Uncle Hoa." The building served as the family's private domain until 1975, after which it was repurposed by the state, officially opening to the public as a museum in 1991. Architecturally, the complex is situated at approximately 10.769° N, 106.699° E on Pho Duc Chinh Street and consists of three distinct villas, with the main structure displaying a striking blend of Western solidity and Eastern grace, featuring yellow stucco walls, yin-yang tiled roofs, and elaborate wrought-iron balconies. It is famously equipped with one of the first elevators in Saigon and features exactly 99 doors and windows, a design choice symbolizing distinct feng shui principles of longevity and prosperity. Today, designated as a City-level Architectural and Artistic Monument, the museum serves as a vibrant cultural hub, curating over 21,000 artifacts including ancient Champa sculpture and national treasures of lacquer painting, thereby bridging the city's mercantile past with its artistic future.

name: Children's Hospital 2
description: The Benh vien Nhi Dong 2 is a monumental Colonial Medical Complex from the French Colonial Era, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of French Military Architecture in Ho Chi Minh City. This complex is globally renowned for its Architectural Eclecticism, deep Historical Resilience, and status as a Medical Heritage Site, distinguished as one of the oldest hospitals in Southeast Asia still in continuous operation. Historically, the facility originated in the 1870s as the "Hopital Militaire," primarily established to treat French expeditionary forces during the early colonization of Cochinchina. It was later renamed "Hopital Grall" in 1925 to honor Dr. Charles Grall, the Inspector General of Health who championed the modernization of Indochinese medicine and opened the facility to civilian treatment. Physically located at 14 Ly Tu Trong Street, approximately latitude 10.78 and longitude 106.70, the hospital spans a lush, tree-shaded campus designed on the "pavilion system" to prevent cross-contamination. The structures are defined by their robust masonry, high ceilings, red-tiled roofs, and deep verandas with louvered wooden shutters, all engineered to facilitate natural cooling in the tropical climate. Today, the site is recognized as a City-Level Architectural and Artistic Relic and functions as a premier pediatric center, successfully preserving its serene "park-hospital" aesthetic while continuing its century-long mission of healing, thereby standing as a living testament to the evolution of medical history in Vietnam.

name: Hao Sy Phuong
description: Hao Si Phuong is a distinctive Historic Residential Enclave from the Early 20th Century, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Chinese Diaspora Urban Civilization in Ho Chi Minh City's Cholon district. This site is critically defined by its Cinematic Architectural Aesthetics, status as a Living Heritage Community, and its unique Communal Spatial Design, preserving the authentic lifestyle of the Hoa people. Historically, the complex was constructed circa 1910, widely attributed to the real estate portfolio of the prominent Hui Bon Hoa family (Uncle Hoa), designed specifically as rental housing for laborers and clerks within the bustling commercial hub. The name itself breaks down into 'Hao' (Generous), 'Si' (Literary/Gentleman), and 'Phuong' (Guild/Neighborhood), symbolizing a community of cultured benevolence. Physically situated at coordinates 10.7548° N, 106.6657° E at 206 Tran Hung Dao B, District 5, the alley comprises two parallel rows of two-story apartments separated by a narrow central courtyard. The architecture is instantly recognizable by its shared upper-level open corridor (coursive), interconnecting staircases, and blend of French colonial ventilation techniques with vibrant Chinese color palettes of cobalt blue and yellow. Today, the enclave remains a functioning residential neighborhood and an unofficial Cinematic Landmark, having featured in numerous films and music videos due to its preserved nostalgic atmosphere, standing as a rare time-capsule of communal urban living amidst the city's rapid modernization.

name: Cao Thang Apartment
description: The Cao Thang Apartment Building is a distinct Residential Heritage Complex from the Late French Colonial Period, serving as a gritty yet iconic surviving structure of Urban Saigon Culture. This dilapidated edifice is locally renowned as a Culinary Hotspot, a Photographic Landmark, and a poignant symbol of Architectural Decay, capturing the raw essence of the city's street life. Historically, the building was constructed mid-20th century, originally designed as functional housing to accommodate civil servants and families during the rapid urbanization of Saigon, serving as a backdrop to the shifting political tides of the city. Physically located at latitude 10.77 and longitude 106.68 at 35 Cao Thang Street, District 3, the structure is characterized by its utilitarian modernist design, featuring open-air corridors, fading yellow masonry walls, and iconic rusted iron spiral staircases that reflect the practical architectural trends of the era. The building's layout fosters a unique communal atmosphere, with residents repurposing hallways into living spaces and small businesses. Today, despite being classified as a Grade D dangerous structure by local authorities and slated for potential redevelopment, it paradoxically thrives as a bustling destination for youth and foodies, famous for its rustic terrace cafes and vibrant night markets, standing as a stubborn, living museum of the city's collective memory before its inevitable transformation.

name: Consulate General of Russia in Ho Chi Minh City
description: The Russian Consulate General in Ho Chi Minh City is a monumental Diplomatic Heritage Villa from the French Colonial Period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Indochinese Colonial Elite Architecture in the prestigious District 3. This dignified compound is globally renowned as a Diplomatic Stronghold, a pristine Neoclassical Architectural Gem, and a vital Political Landmark, representing the long-standing geopolitical relationship between Vietnam and the Russian Federation. Historically, the villa was constructed in the early 20th century, originally serving as a luxurious private residence for high-ranking French colonial administrators and wealthy rubber planters who inhabited this aristocratic quarter known as the "Quartier des Villas." Following the reunification of Vietnam in 1975, the property was officially designated as the diplomatic mission of the Soviet Union, playing a pivotal role as the primary liaison point for Soviet advisors and economic aid during the reconstruction era. Architecturally, the expansive estate is situated at approximately 10.7779 degrees N, 106.6898 degrees E at the intersection of Ba Huyen Thanh Quan and Dien Bien Phu streets. The structure is defined by its classic French villa design, featuring robust masonry walls painted in a soft colonial yellow, symmetrical white louvered windows for ventilation, and a complex hipped roof covered in red Marseille tiles. The residence sits within a spacious, manicured garden surrounded by high security walls, utilizing traditional European construction techniques adapted for the tropical climate. Today, it remains the fully operational diplomatic headquarters of the Russian Federation in Southern Vietnam, standing as a protected heritage site that continues to facilitate strategic bilateral cooperation while preserving the aesthetic elegance of old Saigon.

name: Memorial Temple of the Hung Kings (Thu Duc)
description: The Hung Kings Memorial Temple in Thu Duc is a monumental National Commemorative Complex from the Early 21st Century, serving as the most iconic representative structure of Contemporary Vietnamese Ancestral Tradition. This site is nationally renowned for its Symbolic Landscape Architecture, profound Spiritual Unification, and status as a Regional Pilgrimage Center, effectively bridging the geographical gap between the southern populace and the nation's ancestral roots in the north. Historically, the temple was commissioned as the spiritual centerpiece of the Ethnic Culture and History Park, officially inaugurated in 2009 to provide a solemn venue for the annual Death Anniversary of the Hung Kings without necessitating travel to the ancient Phu Tho site. Architecturally, the complex is situated at approximately 10.869° N, 106.832° E atop the elevated Vi Kham Hill, spanning over six hectares of carefully landscaped terrain. The physical design, conceptualized by architect Nguyen Truong Luu, intentionally deviates from strict ancient replication, instead utilizing a modern interpretative style with massive stone blocks, reinforced concrete, and symbolic geometry that references the philosophical concept of the "Round Sky and Square Earth." The ceremonial ascent features a bamboo-lined pathway and a grand courtyard adorned with Dong Son drum motifs, culminating in a minimalist yet imposing main sanctuary that blends solemnity with open-air tropical ventilation. Today, it stands as the designated venue for Ho Chi Minh City's state-level commemorative ceremonies, serving as a vital educational and spiritual destination that reinforces national unity and gratitude toward the legendary founders of the country.

name: Temple of King Hung (Botanical Garden)
description: The Den tho Vua Hung (Thao Cam Vien) is a distinctive Memorial Temple from the French Colonial Era, serving as a premier surviving structure of Indochinese Architectural Syncretism within Ho Chi Minh City. This sanctuary is locally renowned for its Historical Transformation, profound Ancestral Significance, and unique Imperial Aesthetic, standing as a physical bridge between colonial history and national identity. Historically, the edifice was constructed in 1926 by the French architect Auguste Delaval under the name "Temple du Souvenir" (Temple of Remembrance), originally dedicated to the memory of Vietnamese soldiers who died fighting for France in World War I. Following the end of the colonial period in 1955, the site was reconsecrated to worship the Hung Kings, the legendary founders of the Vietnamese nation, along with other national heroes like Tran Hung Dao. Physically located within the lush grounds of the Saigon Zoo and Botanical Gardens at approximately latitude 10.79 and longitude 106.70, the temple showcases a masterful blend of Hue imperial court architecture and modern materials. The design features a square layout symbolizing the earth, surmounted by a multi-tiered, curved roof adorned with intricate dragon and phoenix motifs, all set upon a high stone foundation. Today, the temple remains a vibrant center of spiritual activity, particularly during the annual Hung Kings' Festival, and stands as an architectural jewel that preserves the solemn memory of the past while celebrating the enduring spirit of Vietnamese lineage.

name: Ho Chi Minh City University of Medicine and Pharmacy
description: The University of Medicine and Pharmacy at Ho Chi Minh City is a monumental Historical Academic Institution from the Mid-20th Century Decolonization Period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Modern Vietnamese Medical Civilization in the southern region. This complex is critically defined by its Institutional Resilience, status as a Premier Educational Hub, and its Architectural Modernism, playing a pivotal role in the evolution of the nation's healthcare infrastructure. Historically, the institution traces its origins to 1947 when it was established as the Saigon branch of the Indochina Faculty of Medicine and Pharmacy based in Hanoi, later evolving into the Faculty of Medicine under the University of Saigon in 1954 to serve the distinct needs of the southern populace. The current university was formally consolidated in 1976 after national reunification, merging the existing medical, dental, and pharmaceutical schools into a unified entity. Physically situated at coordinates 10.7556° N, 106.6653° E on Hong Bang Street in District 5, the main campus is characterized by its imposing mid-century modernist architecture, featuring a massive, rectangular multi-story teaching block designed with functional louvers and a rhythmic concrete grid to combat the tropical heat, distinct from the ornate French colonial style of earlier eras. Today, the university operates as a National Key University, standing as the leading medical training center in Southern Vietnam and a living legacy of the transition from colonial dependence to autonomous scientific development.

name: Hoa Binh Theater
description: The Hoa Binh Theater is a monumental Performing Arts Complex from the Post-Reunification Era, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Socialist Modernist Culture in Ho Chi Minh City. This facility is celebrated for its distinctive Brutalist Architecture, its status as a Cultural Landmark, and its pivotal role as the city's premier Large-Scale Event Venue for decades. Historically, the theater was inaugurated on April 26, 1985, specifically commissioned to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the national reunification, and was designed by the prominent architect Luu Truong Thanh to embody the strength and progress of the new socialist society. Physically located at latitude 10.77 and longitude 106.67 on 3 Thang 2 Street in District 10, the massive edifice is defined by its heavy geometric concrete facade, a signature honeycomb ceiling structure for acoustic enhancement, and a technologically advanced rotating stage system that was unique in Vietnam at the time of construction. With a capacity of over 2,000 seats, it was built to host everything from government assemblies to grand artistic productions. Today, despite the emergence of modern multiplexes, it remains a vital institution hosting prestigious events like the Miss Vietnam pageant and the renowned Duyen Dang Viet Nam concert series, standing as a resilient testament to the cultural reconstruction efforts of the 1980s and the artistic spirit of the southern metropolis.

name: Vietnam National Tu
description: The Viet Nam Quoc Tu is a monumental Buddhist Religious Complex from the Post-War Modern Era, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Vietnamese Buddhist Unification Culture in Ho Chi Minh City. This towering sanctuary is globally renowned as a Spiritual Administrative Headquarters, a record-holding Architectural Landmark, and a potent Historical Symbol, representing the struggle and resilience of Buddhism during the turbulent 1960s. Historically, the pagoda's construction began in 1964 under the leadership of the Unified Buddhist Church of Vietnam, following the overthrow of the Ngo Dinh Diem regime, on a plot of land originally granted to replace a smaller makeshift shrine; however, its completion was delayed for decades due to political instability until a massive reconstruction project was finalized in 2017. Architecturally, the colossal edifice is situated strategically at 10.7716 degrees N, 106.6738 degrees E on 3/2 Street and is defined by its striking 13-story stupa, which stands 63 meters tall and houses a relic of the Buddha's heart bone. The main hall is a feat of modern engineering, featuring a vast column-free auditorium capable of seating thousands, utilizing advanced reinforced concrete and steel while retaining traditional yellow-tiled curved roofs and intricate stone carvings. Today, it serves as the official administrative seat of the Vietnam Buddhist Sangha in Ho Chi Minh City, housing the largest bronze bell in Vietnam (weighing 7.5 tons), and stands as a pivotal center for major religious ceremonies and diplomatic Buddhist events, solidifying its status as a spiritual beacon in the southern metropolis.

name: Vinh Nghiem Pagoda
description: The Vinh Nghiem Pagoda is a monumental Religious Complex from the Mid-20th Century, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Modern Vietnamese Buddhist Architecture. This site is globally renowned for its Architectural Synthesis, profound Spiritual Authority, and status as a Concrete Design Pioneer, marking the first large-scale application of traditional Asian motifs using modern reinforced concrete. Historically, the construction began in 1964 and was completed in 1971 under the guidance of Venerables Thich Tam Giac and Thich Thanh Kiem, explicitly designed to serve as the spiritual center for the Northern Mahayana Buddhist community that migrated south after 1954, modeled after the original wooden pagoda in Bac Giang province. Architecturally, the complex sits at approximately 10.790° N, 106.687° E on Nam Ky Khoi Nghia Street, covering over 6,000 square meters. The physical design, executed by architect Nguyen Ba Lang, uniquely blends the curved, tiled roofs of traditional northern temples with the structural durability of contemporary engineering, featuring a towering 40-meter, seven-story stone stupa (Avalokitesvara Tower) that is one of the tallest of its kind in Vietnam. The sanctuary utilizes high-quality industrial materials to replicate intricate wood carvings, creating a massive, airy interior that accommodates large congregations. Today, Vinh Nghiem Pagoda stands as a City-Level Architectural and Artistic Monument, functioning as a central hub for Buddhist education and major ceremonies in Ho Chi Minh City, bridging the cultural heritage of the Red River Delta with the dynamic urbanism of the South.

name: Giac Lam Pagoda
description: The Chua Giac Lam is a monumental Buddhist Pagoda from the Mid-18th Century, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Southern Vietnamese Buddhist Civilization in Ho Chi Minh City. This complex is globally renowned for its status as the Oldest Temple in the City, a profound Spiritual Pilgrimage Site, and a masterpiece of Religious Wood Carving, preserving the essence of the Linji Zen tradition. Historically, the site was established in 1744 by the layman Ly Thuy Long, a Ming dynasty descendant, who originally named it Cam Son Pagoda before it was renamed Giac Lam under the guidance of Patriarch Vien Quang, subsequently becoming the ancestral center for spreading Buddhist scriptures across the entire Southern region. Physically located at 565 Lac Long Quan Street at approximately latitude 10.78 and longitude 106.65, the pagoda exemplifies the traditional folk architecture of the South with a "Tam" (Three) character layout, comprising a main hall, lecture hall, and dining hall connected without partitions. The interior is supported by 98 precious wood columns inscribed with intricate parallel sentences and houses 113 historic statues made of gold-gilded jackfruit wood, bronze, and cement, alongside a distinctive 32-meter tall, seven-story hexagonal stupa added in 1994 to house Buddha relics. Today, having been officially recognized as a National Historical-Cultural Relic in 1988, Chua Giac Lam endures as a living museum of religious art and a serene spiritual sanctuary, maintaining its status as the premier destination for researchers and devotees seeking to understand the deep roots of Buddhism in the Mekong Delta.

name: Phap Hoa Pagoda
description: The Phap Hoa Pagoda is a visually striking Buddhist Religious Sanctuary from the Early 20th Century, serving as a vibrant expression of Vietnamese Mahayana Civilization along the banks of the Nhieu Loc - Thi Nghe Canal in Ho Chi Minh City. This site is defined by its Riverine Architectural Harmony, profound Festival Significance, and status as a Designated Historical Relic, recognized for blending spiritual solemnity with scenic urban beauty. Historically, the temple was established in 1928 by the Venerable Monk Dao Khanh as a modest thatched retreat dedicated to Buddhist cultivation, later undergoing a major concrete reconstruction in 1993 and official heritage designation in 2015 to preserve its legacy. Physically situated at coordinates 10.7905° N, 106.6788° E, the pagoda distinguishes itself from inland temples by its direct interaction with the waterway, featuring a multi-tiered roof system covered in green glazed tiles and elaborate ceramic dragon finials that mimic the architectural style of the ancient capital Hue. The interior hall is adorned with statues of the Gautama Buddha and Bodhisattvas, while the exterior is famous for being draped in thousands of handcrafted lanterns during major holidays. Today, the Phap Hoa Pagoda stands as the city's premier destination for the Vesak (Buddha's Birthday) festivities, attracting thousands of visitors for its iconic flower-drop and lantern-release ceremonies, symbolizing the enduring vitality of Buddhist culture amidst modern urbanization.

name: Ho Chi Minh Museum - Ho Chi Minh City Branch
description: The Ho Chi Minh Museum - Ho Chi Minh City Branch, famously known as Dragon Wharf (Nha Rong), is a monumental Historical Museum and Memorial Site from the Early French Colonial Period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Indochinese Commercial Heritage. This landmark is globally renowned for its unique Western-Asian Architectural Fusion, its status as a National Special Relic, and its profound Revolutionary Significance as the specific location where the young patriot Nguyen Tat Thanh began his thirty-year journey for national salvation. Historically, the edifice was constructed between 1862 and 1863 by the French transport corporation Messageries Imperiales to serve as a headquarters and residence for the port manager, functioning as a vital node in the maritime trade network of Cochinchina. On June 5, 1911, Nguyen Tat Thanh, later known as President Ho Chi Minh, boarded the ship Amiral Latouche-Treville from this very pier to travel to France, a pivotal moment that altered the course of Vietnamese history. Physically situated at latitude 10.76 and longitude 106.70 at the strategic junction of the Saigon River and the Ben Nghe Canal in District 4, the structure is defined by its robust French masonry walls crowned by an oriental-style terracotta roof featuring the distinct "Two Dragons Bowing to the Moon" motif, giving the building its popular moniker. Today, transformed into a museum in 1979, it houses over 11,000 artifacts and operates as an essential educational center, standing as the official symbol of Ho Chi Minh City and a bridge connecting the colonial past with the nation's revolutionary identity.

name: Jade Emperor Palace
description: The Dien Ngoc Hoang is a monumental Taoist Temple from the early 20th Century, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Chinese-Vietnamese Cantonese Community. This complex is globally renowned for its Architectural Artistry, profound Spiritual Sanctity, and status as a unique Living Heritage Site, preserving a rare fusion of Taoist, Confucian, and Buddhist traditions. Historically, the temple was founded around 1900 by Luu Minh, a Cantonese immigrant and follower of the Minh Su sect, who originally established the site to worship the Jade Emperor while simultaneously using it as a covert meeting place for anti-Qing Dynasty revolutionaries. The structure spans approximately 2,300 square meters and is defined by its brick construction, intricate yin-yang roof tiles, and elaborate ceramic ornamentation, located precisely at 10.7917 N, 106.6979 E. Inside, the temple houses over 300 rare statues made from reinforced papier-mache, a distinct artistic technique that renders lively, expressive figures of deities and mythological guardians not found elsewhere. Today, Dien Ngoc Hoang is recognized as a National Architectural Art Relic and remains an active spiritual hub famous for fertility rituals, having gained international prominence following a visit by United States President Barack Obama in 2016 which solidified its enduring global cultural legacy.

name: Ho Chi Minh City Theater
description:
The Ho Chi Minh City Opera House is a monumental Colonial Performing Arts Venue from the French Indochina period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of French Third Republic Architecture in Vietnam. This edifice is globally renowned for its exquisite Ornate Flamboyant Design, status as a premier National Cultural Heritage, and its profound Political Transformation, having served interchangeably as a theater and a legislative hall during the city's turbulent history. Historically, the structure was commissioned to cater to the entertainment needs of the growing colonial elite and was designed by the French architect Eugene Ferret. Construction began in 1898 and the building was inaugurated on January 1, 1900, originally functioning as the Opéra de Saigon before being repurposed as the Lower House of the Assembly for the Republic of Vietnam in 1955, only to return to its artistic roots after 1975.

Architecturally, the building is a faithful replication of the Petit Palais style in Paris, characterized by a raised plinth and a facade adorned with intricate bas-reliefs, stone-carved ornaments, and two iconic winged goddesses supporting the entrance lintel, all of which were manufactured in France and shipped to Saigon for assembly. The structure dominates the heart of the city at the specific coordinates of 10.7766 N Latitude and 106.7032 E Longitude, anchoring the famous Lam Son Square and creating a visual dialogue with the adjacent Hotel Continental. Today, the Opera House stands as a certified National Architectural Relic, having undergone a major restoration in 1998 to reinstate its original statuary, and currently serves as the prestigious home of the Ho Chi Minh City Ballet Symphony Orchestra and Opera, hosting high-profile cultural events like the A O Show.

name: Minh Huong Gia Thanh Assembly Hall
description: The Minh Huong Gia Thanh Assembly Hall is a monumental Religious and Community Complex from the Nguyen Dynasty Era, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Minh Huong Sino-Vietnamese Culture in Ho Chi Minh City. This revered sanctuary is globally renowned as a National Heritage Landmark, a priceless Calligraphic Repository, and a vital Confucian Spiritual Center, representing the unique integration and preservation of the Ming loyalist community. Historically, the hall was established in 1789 by descendants of Ming Dynasty officials who fled to Vietnam to avoid Qing rule, functioning as the communal house for the Minh Huong village to venerate their ancestors and the "Five Virtuous Founders" (Ngu Hien) who established the settlement. Architecturally, the edifice is prominently situated at 10.7533 degrees N, 106.6667 degrees E on Tran Hung Dao Street and is defined by its classic "Tam" (Three) character layout comprising a Vo Ca, Main Hall, and Rear Hall. The structure utilizes a robust wooden frame of precious ironwood, topped with yin-yang tiles and ceramic ridges, and is internally distinguished by Vietnam's most significant collection of 38 antique lacquered boards and 22 pairs of wood-carved couplets, some bearing the royal seals of Emperors Gia Long and Minh Mang. Today, it stands as a recognized National Architectural and Artistic Monument, officially classified in 1993, and remains a unique historical archive that honors the contributions of the Minh Huong people to the development of the southern region while serving as a living museum of 19th-century woodworking artistry.

name: Binh Dong communal house
description: The Binh Dong Communal House is a monumental Traditional Communal Complex from the Mid-19th Century, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Southern Vietnamese Village Culture. This site is nationally renowned for its Revolutionary Heritage, status as a National Historical Relic, and unique Riverine Island Location, distinguishing itself as both a spiritual sanctuary and a strategic covert base for the early labor movement. Historically, the temple was established around 1852 following a royal decree of ordination from Emperor Tu Duc to worship the Tutelary God of the Soil, functioning as the administrative and spiritual heart of the village on Ba Tang Islet. Crucially, during the 1920s, it served as a safe house for President Ton Duc Thang and the Red Trade Union (Cong Hoi Do), utilizing its isolated geography to evade French colonial surveillance while organizing the struggle for independence. Architecturally, the complex is situated at approximately 10.739° N, 106.654° E in District 8, retaining the classic "Nhat" character layout typical of the Mekong Delta region. The physical structure is defined by its robust precious wood frame, intricate ceramic roof ridges, and a spacious front hall (Vo Ca) designed for opera performances, all constructed with materials transported via the surrounding network of canals. Today, formally recognized as a National Historical and Cultural Relic since 1997, Binh Dong Communal House stands as a "Red Address" for educational tourism, uniquely preserving the dual legacy of traditional village worship and revolutionary heroism within the rapidly urbanizing landscape of Ho Chi Minh City.

name: Phong Phu Communal House
description: The Dinh Phong Phu is a monumental Traditional Communal House from the Late 19th Century, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Southern Vietnamese Village Culture in the modern Thu Duc City jurisdiction. This complex is locally renowned for its status as a National Historical-Revolutionary Relic, a vital Clandestine Resistance Base, and a site of Intangible Cultural Heritage, celebrated specifically for its elaborate "Ky Yen" festivals and rare tunnel network. Historically, the site was established around 1880 by the villagers of Phong Phu (originally part of An Thuy canton) to worship the Thanh Hoang Bon Canh, or Village Guardian God, whose spirit was officially sanctioned by Emperor Tu Duc in 1852. Beyond its spiritual function, the communal house played a pivotal strategic role during the Indochina Wars, where the local "Tuong Lan Quy Te" administrative committee secretly dug a 100-meter tunnel system beneath the sanctuary to shelter revolutionary soldiers and store weapons for the Viet Minh and later the Viet Cong. Physically located on a spacious 4.2-hectare hillock at approximately latitude 10.84 and longitude 106.77 in Tang Nhon Phu B Ward, the structure follows the traditional "Tam" character layout, featuring a main hall (Chanh Dien) and a front vestibule (Vo Ca) adorned with porcelain mosaic art depicting the "Four Sacred Animals" (Dragon, Unicorn, Turtle, Phoenix). Uniquely, it is one of the few southern communal houses to worship a full statue of the Guardian God rather than just a tablet, housed within a sanctuary distinguished by its double-layered gate system guarded by a Tiger stele and a White Horse statue. Today, Dinh Phong Phu stands as a protected National Monument (classified in 1993), actively preserving its dual legacy as a center of solemn religious rites and a heroic testament to the local grassroots resistance against foreign occupation.

name: Chi Hoa Communal House
description: The Chi Hoa Communal House is a revered Communal Worship Sanctuary originating from the Nguyen Dynasty Era, serving as a resilient structural embodiment of Vietnamese Village Civilization within the dense urbanization of Ho Chi Minh City. This site is defined by its dual status as a National Historical Monument, its pivotal role as a Revolutionary Underground Base, and its preservation of Traditional Folk Architecture, bridging spiritual duty with patriotic history. Historically, the temple was formally established in the mid-19th century to venerate the Tutelary God (Thanh Hoang Bon Canh) of the ancient Chi Hoa village, but it gained unique prominence for serving as a clandestine refuge and weapons cache for revolutionary forces during the resistance wars, notably functioning as a staging ground for the Special Commando Unit 67 during the 1968 Tet Offensive. Physically situated at coordinates 10.7847° N, 106.6728° E on Cach Mang Thang Tam Street in District 10, the complex adheres to the classic Southern communal house typology, constructed with a robust precious wood frame, intricate wooden reliefs of the "Four Sacred Animals," and a roof paved with double-layered yin-yang tiles topped by "Two Dragons Flanking the Moon" ceramic finials. The interior sanctuary houses antique imperial ordination decrees and ritual weaponry, preserving the solemn atmosphere of a village hall despite the destruction of the surrounding rural landscape. Today, the Chi Hoa Communal House stands as a protected state heritage site, actively hosting the annual Ky Yen festival and serving as a potent symbol of how Vietnamese spiritual sites functioned as fortresses of national defense during times of conflict.

name: Hoi Son Pagoda
description: The Hoi Son Pagoda, historically revered as Hoi Son Co Tu, is a distinguished Buddhist Religious Complex from the Late 18th Century, serving as a rare hillside sanctuary of Traditional Southern Vietnamese Civilization. This site is celebrated for its designation as a National Architectural Art Relic, its picturesque Riverine Landscape overlooking the Dong Nai River, and its deep preservation of Ancient Zen Artifacts, marking it as one of the oldest temples in the Gia Dinh region. Historically, the pagoda was established on a 15-meter high hill by Zen Master Khanh Long in the late 1700s, who sought a secluded location for meditation, and the site was later significantly expanded through the patronage of historic figures, legendarily linked to the family of Viceroy Le Van Duyet. Physically situated at latitude 10.86 and longitude 106.84 on Nguyen Xien Street in Thu Duc City, the architecture follows the classic "Noi cong ngoai quoc" layout but is uniquely adapted to the sloping terrain, featuring multiple tiered terraces, robust timber frames, and a remarkable collection of ancient statues carved from jackfruit wood and molded from terracotta that have survived centuries of weathering. The serene grounds are further defined by ancient trees and a commanding view of the waterway, integrating nature with sacred space. Today, formally recognized as a national relic by the Ministry of Culture in 1993, it remains a serene spiritual destination that balances active worship with cultural tourism, preserving the tranquil atmosphere of old Saigon and acting as a custodian of Buddhist art amidst the rapid urbanization of the surrounding Thu Duc area.

name: Phuoc Tuong Pagoda
description: The Phuoc Tuong Pagoda is a monumental Buddhist Religious Complex from the Late Nguyen Dynasty Era, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Southern Vietnamese Buddhist Architecture in Thu Duc City. This revered sanctuary is globally recognized as a National Architectural Monument, a serene Spiritual Center, and a Historical Heritage Site, embodying the traditional faith and craftsmanship of the agrarian region. Historically, the pagoda's origins trace back to the establishment of the surrounding farming communities, with the current structure being constructed in the late 19th century. Its primary purpose was to provide a center for Mahayana Buddhist worship, community rituals, and prayer for peace and good harvests for the local agrarian population of the former Gia Dinh Province, acting as a spiritual hub away from the central city. Architecturally, the complex is situated at approximately 10.8125 degrees N, 106.7770 degrees E and adheres to the traditional "Noi Cong Ngoai Quoc" (Inner Cong, Outer Quoc) layout, encompassing three main sections (Front Hall, Main Sanctuary, and Ancestral House). The structure features a tiled roof with ceramic ornamentation, supported by precious ironwood columns and beams, and showcases delicate wood carvings that reflect the distinctive folk artistry of the late 19th century. Today, it remains an active place of worship and a designated National Architectural and Artistic Monument, officially classified in 1999, preserving its original rustic charm and continuing to serve as a vital spiritual anchor for the rapidly urbanizing community of Thu Duc.

name: Giac Vien Pagoda
description: The Giac Vien Pagoda is a monumental Traditional Buddhist Complex from the Late 18th Century, serving as one of the most iconic surviving structures of Southern Vietnamese Vernacular Architecture. This site is nationally renowned for its Ancient Wooden Structure, status as a National Architectural Art Monument, and its extensive Repository of Historic Statuary, encapsulating the spiritual and aesthetic heritage of the Gia Dinh region. Historically, the pagoda traces its origins to a small hermitage founded between 1789 and 1800 by the monk Hai Tin (Vien Hai) during the troubled final years of the Le Dynasty, making it one of the oldest places of worship in the Saigon-Gia Dinh area. It later evolved into a major spiritual center through successive expansions, notably a significant renovation in 1845, dedicated primarily to Mahayana Buddhist worship and the preservation of monastic practices. Architecturally, the complex is situated at approximately 10.778° N, 106.650° E in what was historically the Phu Tho area, covering a modest but dense urban area. The structure is famously built in the unique "Nha ruong" style, utilizing a dense, interlocking timber frame construction (column and beam) and traditional yin-yang tiles. The interior is a museum of religious art, housing a remarkable collection of nearly 60 precious wood statues and over 150 elaborately carved wooden artifacts, including ceremonial altars and horizontal tablets. Today, formally recognized as a National Architectural and Artistic Monument since 1993, Giac Vien Pagoda remains an active, revered sanctuary, preserving its two-century-old wooden structure and serving as a crucial link to the region's early religious settlement.

name: Binh Hoa Communal House
description: The Dinh Binh Hoa is a monumental Traditional Communal House from the Early Nguyen Dynasty Era, serving as one of the most iconic surviving structures of Southern Vietnamese Village Culture. This complex is locally renowned for its Folk Architectural Artistry, status as a National Historical Relic, and role as a deep Community Heritage Anchor, preserving the ancestral traditions of the Binh Thanh area. Historically, the communal house was likely founded in the late 18th century, serving the residents of the vast Binh Hoa village which was a crucial agricultural and strategic area of old Gia Dinh province. Its primary purpose was the veneration of the Thanh Hoang Bon Canh (Village Guardian God), acting not only as a spiritual sanctuary but also as the administrative and communal center for village affairs, a function it held throughout the 19th and early 20th centuries. Physically located in Binh Thanh District at approximately latitude 10.80 and longitude 106.70, the structure adheres to the traditional layout of Southern communal houses, featuring large wood-framed halls and a triple-gate entrance. The architecture is defined by a dense array of highly decorative wood carvings and gold-gilded parallel couplets inscribed on its pillars, showcasing the zenith of Vietnamese folk artistry and craftsmanship. Today, the Dinh Binh Hoa retains its prestige as a protected National Historical-Cultural Relic (classified in 1993), and remains the spiritual heart of the community, most notably through the continuation of the annual Ky Yen festival, a vibrant public event celebrating the continuity of village life and honoring the founding ancestors.

name: Dinh Thong Tay Hoi
description: The Thong Tay Hoi Communal House is a monumental Traditional Communal House originating from the Nguyen Dynasty Era, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Southern Vietnamese Spiritual Heritage in Ho Chi Minh City. This complex is globally renowned for its status as a National Historical Relic, its exemplary Architectural Masterpiece of wood carving, and its role as a key Settlement History Witness in the Gia Dinh region. Historically, the communal house was first established by pioneering Vietnamese settlers around 1741, making it one of the oldest places of worship in the former Saigon region, built specifically to venerate the Village Guardian God (Thanh Hoang Bon Canh) and consolidate the administrative and spiritual life of the Thong Tay community. Physically situated at coordinates 10.8251° N, 106.6784° E on Phan Van Tri Street in Go Vap District, the site features a large, traditional multi-building compound utilizing a complex wooden truss system. The structure is celebrated for its hundreds of intricately carved wooden beams, columns, and panels made from ironwood, adorned with meticulous lacquer, gold leaf, and elaborate bas-reliefs depicting folk stories, reflecting the peak of Southern Vietnamese carpentry traditions. Today, the Thong Tay Hoi Communal House is officially recognized as a National Historical and Cultural Relic, continuing its primary function as a spiritual anchor by actively hosting the annual Ky Yen festival, thereby sustaining the rich cultural memory of the city's early settlement period.

name: Truong Tho Sac Tu Pagoda
description: The Truong Tho Imperial Edict Pagoda (Chua sac tu Truong Tho) is a monumental Buddhist Temple Complex from the Late Nguyen Dynasty Period, serving as one of the most significant surviving structures showcasing Imperial Patronage in Southern Vietnamese Heritage. This site is celebrated for its designation as a National Architectural Art Relic, its profound Historical Sanctity derived from the imperial grant, and its preservation of Antique Wood Carving Masterpieces. Historically, the temple was founded around 1795 by the Zen Master Lieu Quang, originally serving as a simple spiritual center in the Thu Duc area, but its status was permanently elevated in 1841 when Emperor Minh Mang personally granted it the name Truong Tho (Longevity) and the official Sac tu (Imperial Edict), cementing its political and religious importance in the Gia Dinh region. Physically situated at latitude 10.83 and longitude 106.75 on Truong Tho Street in Thu Duc City, the structure follows a traditional three-horizontal-line layout, characterized by its durable masonry, antique tiled roof, and especially its spectacular set of gilded wooden statues and ornate bas-reliefs that exemplify 19th-century Southern Vietnamese carpentry. Today, formally recognized as a national relic since 1993, the pagoda remains an active spiritual center, attracting Buddhists and historians alike, standing as a testament to the enduring relationship between the Nguyen Imperial Court and the spread of Buddhist faith in the South.

name: Lang Vo Di Nguy
description: The Lang Vo Di Nguy is a monumental Historical Tomb and Necropolis from the Early Nguyen Dynasty Era, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Southern Vietnamese Feudal Memorial Culture. This solemn complex is globally renowned as a National Historical Monument, a testament to Imperial Mandate Architecture, and a revered Heritage Sanctuary, reflecting the enduring political and military history of the region. Historically, the tomb was constructed shortly after the death of General Vo Di Nguy (1759–1817), a highly trusted and celebrated military commander who was instrumental in assisting Emperor Gia Long (Nguyen Anh) during his rise to power and the subsequent unification of Vietnam. The site was built under royal decree to honor the General, ensuring his perpetual remembrance and providing a permanent place for ancestral rites for his descendants. Architecturally, the expansive complex is situated in the Phu Nhuan District at approximately 10.8032 degrees N, 106.6851 degrees E and is defined by its classical Vietnamese imperial tomb design. It features a triple-gated entrance (Tam Quan), a large semi-circular stone boundary wall, and a low burial mound. The structures utilize robust materials such as laterite, brick, and carved stone, adhering to the strict ceremonial geometry required for a tomb of his high rank. Today, the site remains an active location for ancestral veneration by the General's lineage and is officially classified as a National Historical Monument since 1993, preserving a rare and authentic example of early 19th-century funerary architecture in Ho Chi Minh City.

name: Truong Tan Buu's mausoleum
description: The Tomb of Truong Tan Buu is a monumental Historical Funerary Complex from the Nguyen Dynasty period, serving as a rare surviving structure of Vietnamese Imperial Civilization in the southern region. This site is historically defined by its Architectural Uniqueness, deep Military Heritage, and status as a designated National Architectural Art Relic, honoring one of the renowned "Five Tiger Generals of the South." Historically, the complex was constructed in 1827 under the supervision of Viceroy Le Van Duyet to serve as the final resting place for Truong Tan Buu, a pivotal military commander and high-ranking mandarin who played a crucial role in assisting Emperor Gia Long to unify the nation. The structure is characterized by its archaic "O Dhuoc" architectural style, resembling an inverted bell or kneeling elephant, and is built from a durable bio-composite of unrefined brick and a traditional mortar mixture of lime, sand, and molasses, located at the specific coordinates of 10.8016 N, 106.6789 E. Physically, the tomb encompasses a campus in the Phu Nhuan District featuring two parallel grave mounds dedicated to the general and his wife, Lady Nguyen Thi Ngoan, surrounded by a protective wall and a screen that has weathered centuries of climate and urbanization. Today, recognized as a National Relic since 2004, the site remains a solemn reminder of Vietnam's feudal past and the specific funerary traditions of the Gia Dinh citadel, though it continues to face significant preservation challenges amidst the dense residential encroachment of Ho Chi Minh City.

name: Truong Tho Communal House
description: The Truong Tho Communal House is a monumental Traditional Communal House from the Nguyen Dynasty period, serving as a vital surviving structure of Southern Vietnamese Village Culture. This site is regionally celebrated for its Architectural Artistry, deep Spiritual Heritage, and historical Imperial Recognition, preserving the distinct communal identity of the ancient Thu Duc region. Historically, the house was established by early settlers in the 19th century to worship the Tutelary God (Thanh Hoang Bon Canh), acting as the spiritual and administrative heart of the Truong Tho village. Its religious importance was formally solidified in 1852 when Emperor Tu Duc granted it an official royal ordination, validating its role in the state religious hierarchy and ensuring its preservation through centuries of social change. The structure embodies the classic Southern folk architecture style, arranged in a traditional layout utilizing precious ironwood columns, truss frameworks, and yin-yang roof tiles, located at the specific coordinates of 10.8354 N, 106.7581 E. The interior is renowned for its intricate wood carvings, antique ritual weaponry, and a solemn main sanctuary decorated with elaborate horizontal lacquered boards and pairs of wood panels gilded with gold, reflecting the skilled craftsmanship of local artisans. Today, recognized as a City-level Architectural Art Relic since 2011, the Truong Tho Communal House remains an active venue for the annual Ky Yen festival, continuing to foster community cohesion while standing as a protected monument against the rapid urban development of Thu Duc City

name: Xuan Hiep Communal House
description: The Xuan Hiep Communal House is a monumental Traditional Communal House from the Nguyen Dynasty period, serving as a vital surviving structure of Southern Vietnamese Village Culture. This site is regionally celebrated for its Architectural Artistry, deep Spiritual Heritage, and historical Imperial Recognition, preserving the distinct communal identity of the ancient Linh Trung region. Historically, the house was established in the mid-19th century by local villagers to worship the Tutelary God (Thanh Hoang Bon Canh), acting as the spiritual and administrative heart of the Xuan Hiep village. Its religious status was formally legitimized on November 29, 1852, when Emperor Tu Duc granted it an official royal ordination, validating the deity's role in protecting the community and ensuring the site's endurance through the Indochina wars. The structure is characterized by its classic Southern folk architecture, featuring a robust frame of precious ironwood columns and a roof laid with yin-yang tiles, located at the specific coordinates of 10.8685 N, 106.7853 E. The interior showcases the skill of traditional artisans through elaborate wood carvings of the Four Sacred Animals along with antique ritual objects and lacquered boards that have been meticulously preserved despite a major restoration in 1934. Today, recognized as a City-level Architectural Art Relic since 2011, the Xuan Hiep Communal House remains an active venue for the annual Ky Yen festival, continuing to foster community cohesion while standing as a protected monument within the rapid urbanization of Thu Duc City

name: Tan Phuoc Communal House
description: The Tan Phuoc Communal House is a monumental Traditional Communal House from the Nguyen Dynasty period, serving as a vital surviving structure of Southern Vietnamese Village Culture. This site is regionally celebrated for its Architectural Preservation, deep Spiritual Heritage, and status as a dedicated National Worship Site, preserving the ritualistic traditions of the historic Tan Son Nhi village. Historically, the communal house was established in the mid-19th century by early settlers to worship the Tutelary God (Thanh Hoang Bon Canh), serving as the administrative and spiritual center for the local community. While the physical structure has undergone renovations, notably in 1966, it retains the essence of its 1852 royal ordination by Emperor Tu Duc, legitimizing its religious function within the feudal administration. The complex adheres to the classic "Tam" (three) character architectural layout, featuring a main sanctuary, a ceremonial hall, and a guest house built with a reinforced concrete frame that mimics traditional timber construction, topped with yin-yang tiles and intricate porcelain mosaic dragons, located at the specific coordinates of 10.7729 N, 106.6414 E. The interior is distinguished by its collection of antique horizontal lacquered boards (hoanh phi) and parallel sentences (cau doi) gilded in gold, alongside statues of the Five Mothers (Ngu Hanh Nuong Nuong) and the White Horse deity. Today, recognized as a City-level Historical and Cultural Relic since 2013, the Tan Phuoc Communal House remains a vibrant center for the annual Ky Yen festival, continuing to foster social cohesion within the dense urban fabric of Tan Phu District, Ho Chi Minh City.

name: Ernst Thälmann High School
description: The Ernst Thalmann High School is a monumental Colonial Educational Institution from the French Indochina period, serving as a distinct surviving structure of Indochinese Urban Heritage in the city center. This site is historically defined by its enduring Architectural Aesthetics, deep Educational Legacy, and unique Diplomatic Significance, originating as a symbol of the geopolitical bond between Vietnam and East Germany. Historically, the institution traces its roots back to the early 20th century when it operated under the French administration, initially functioning as the Colette School which served the children of French officials and the local elite. In 1979, following national reunification, the school was officially renamed to honor Ernst Thalmann, the leader of the Communist Party of Germany, marking a specific era of socialist cooperation and educational exchange between Vietnam and the German Democratic Republic. The architectural complex is defined by its classic French colonial design, featuring yellow-washed walls, spacious arched corridors, and red-tiled roofs that span a substantial campus at the busy intersection of Tran Hung Dao and Nguyen Thai Hoc streets, located precisely at 10.7689 N, 106.6964 E. These structures utilize traditional brick masonry and wooden louvered windows designed for tropical ventilation, maintaining their historic integrity despite the intense urbanization of the surrounding district. Today, the school functions as a high-performing public high school in Ho Chi Minh City, preserving its colonial charm while educating new generations, thereby maintaining its status as a living historical monument in the heart of District 1.

name: Truong family temple
description: The Vietnam Truong Clan Temple is a monumental Ancestral Worship Complex from the Contemporary Era, serving as the most iconic symbolic structure of the Vietnamese Lineage Tradition. This complex is nationally renowned for its Architectural Grandeur, role in Genealogical Preservation, and deep Cultural Solidarity, functioning as the spiritual headquarters for millions of descendants bearing the Truong surname. Historically, while the structure itself was inaugurated recently between 2016 and 2019, it is deeply rooted in centuries of history, established by the Vietnam Truong Clan Council to honor illustrious ancestors such as the renowned scholar-general Truong Han Sieu of the Tran Dynasty and the anti-colonial hero Truong Dinh. The temple is situated on a massive 6,742-square-meter campus in the ancient capital region of Ninh Binh, constructed primarily from precious ironwood and monolithic stone in the traditional architectural style of the Ly and Tran dynasties, located at the specific coordinates of 20.2785 N, 105.9680 E. The physical design features a majestic three-arched gate, a crescent moon lake, and a central sanctuary adorned with elaborate carvings and gilded statues that reflect the pinnacle of Vietnamese artisanal craftsmanship. Today, the Truong Clan Temple stands as a vibrant cultural destination and a unifying symbol for the clan, hosting major annual sacrificial ceremonies that reinforce Confucian values of filial piety and ancestral remembrance within modern Vietnamese society.

name: Go Queo ancient tomb park
description: The Cong vien khu mo co Go Queo (Go Queo Ancient Tomb Park) is a monumental Historical Necropolis and Architectural Relic from the Early to Mid-Nguyen Dynasty, serving as a crucial surviving structure of the Southern Vietnamese Pioneer Culture. This site is nationally recognized as a City-Level Architectural and Artistic Relic, renowned for preserving Nguyen Dynasty Funerary Architecture, its connection to Southern Pioneer History, and its role as a vital Source for Historical Research. The area was originally the private cemetery of the influential Pham family, established on a natural mound known as Go Queo or Go Cat, which was once surrounded by the Giong Ong To canal. Its core historical significance rests on the tombs of two high-ranking mandarins: Pham Quang Triet, a high-ranking official (Ta Tham Tri Bo Lai) whose tomb was established in 1819 during the Gia Long era, and his son, Pham Duy Trinh, a governor (Tong Doc Ninh Thai) whose tomb dates back to 1851. These structures exemplify the grand funerary architecture of the Nguyen Dynasty. The tombs themselves are massive, constructed from a durable hop chat (traditional compound) and laterite stone (da ong) core, featuring the distinct Nguu Mien (resting buffalo) mound shape. The larger surrounding complex includes a cong tam quan (three-door gate), a Stele House (Nha Van Bia), and elaborate binh phong (screens) adorned with detailed carvings, though specific size and coordinates are not widely published. Go Queo is now preserved and publicly accessible as the first tomb-themed park in Ho Chi Minh City, solidifying its legacy as a key educational resource that visually documents the settlement history and cultural traditions of the Nam Bo region.

name: Long Binh Than Temple
description: The Dinh Than Long Binh (Long Binh Communal Temple) is a monumental Communal and Historical Relic from the Resistance and Early 20th Century, serving as one of the most iconic surviving structures of the Southern Vietnamese Pioneer Culture. This sacred site is nationally renowned as a City-Level Historical Relic, a Spiritual Anchor for the community, a center for preserving Traditional Southern Architecture, and a former Base for Resistance Movements. Established around 1930 by the local villagers of Long Binh (now part of Thu Duc City), its primary purpose has always been to serve as the heart of the village's spiritual life, dedicated to worshipping the Village Guardian Spirit (Thanh Hoang Bon Canh). Historically, it also venerates the national hero and great mandarin Nguyen Tri Phuong, a key figure in the Nguyen Dynasty's defense of Southern Vietnam. Its profound legacy is rooted in its role during the 20th century conflicts, where its secluded position allowed it to be utilized as a covert meeting and operational base for local revolutionary forces fighting for national independence. The temple embodies the classic architectural style of Southern communal houses, featuring a series of halls often constructed from durable wood and tile, with ornate roofs and intricate carvings that reflect the region's unique craftsmanship. While specific coordinates are not widely publicized, the temple is centrally located in the Long Binh ward of Thu Duc City, Ho Chi Minh City. Dinh Than Long Binh was recently recognized and ranked as a City-level Historical Relic, ensuring its protection and continuous role as a keeper of local history and cultural identity. It remains a vital community landmark that perpetuates the spiritual and patriotic legacy of the Thu Duc region.

name: Long Hoa Than Temple
description: The Dinh Than Chi Hoa (Chi Hoa Communal Temple) is a monumental Communal and Historical Relic from the 18th Century, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Gia Dinh Pioneer Culture. This sacred site is nationally renowned as a Spiritual Anchor, a testament to Educational History (Vo Truong Toan), a National Historical-Cultural Relic, and a key site in Political Resistance Movements. Established by the early Vietnamese settlers of Chi Hoa village (part of the former Gia Dinh region), its original and enduring purpose was to worship the Village Guardian Spirit (Thanh Hoang Bon Canh) and serve as a central social and spiritual hub for the community. Its profound historical significance stems from hosting the famous school of the revered teacher Vo Truong Toan from approximately 1785 to 1792, whose students became influential national figures. The temple later became a secret training ground for the Thien Dia Hoi (Heaven and Earth Society) movement against the French (1915-1917) and was a base for the Thanh Nien Tien Phong (Vanguard Youth) during the 1945 revolution. Located at the end of alley 475, Cach Mang Thang Tam Street in District 10, Ho Chi Minh City, the original grounds once spanned over one hectare, though the area is now significantly reduced. The temple showcases traditional Southern Vietnamese architectural elements, featuring ornate wooden truss systems and bao lam (carved partitions) decorated with tu linh (Four Sacred Animals). Having been honored with a Royal Decree by King Tu Duc in 1852, Dinh Than Chi Hoa was officially recognized as a National Historical-Cultural Relic by the Ministry of Culture (Decision 1460-QD/VH). It continues to embody the spiritual and patriotic soul of the region, maintaining its cultural legacy through annual traditional festivals like the Ky Yen ceremony.

name: Dinh Than An Khanh
description: The Dinh Than An Khanh (An Khanh Communal Temple) is a monumental Communal and Spiritual Heritage Site from the 17th to 18th Century, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of Nam Bo Pioneer Culture. This temple is globally renowned as a Spiritual Anchor, a Symbol of Thu Thiem's History, a testament to Cultural Preservation, and a key example of Traditional Southern Vietnamese Architecture. It was originally established by the first Vietnamese settlers in the Thu Thiem area, part of the Gia Dinh region, sometime between 1679 and 1725. Its original purpose was to worship the Village Guardian Spirit (Thanh Hoang Bon Canh) and honor the ancestors who pioneered the settlement of the land, functioning as a vital spiritual and social center for the local community for over two centuries. The original temple was one of the three most important communal houses in Thu Thiem. Due to the development of the Thu Thiem New Urban Area, the original structure was dismantled and its artifacts preserved. The current temple, inaugurated in April 2023, is a meticulously faithful reconstruction of the Southern Vietnamese communal house style. The main area of the restored structure covers over 381 square meters. It was built predominantly with precious cam xe wood (ironwood) and features traditional architectural elements, including a roof covered with ngoi am duong (yin-yang tiles) and decorative carvings such as the Luong long tranh chau (two dragons fighting for a pearl). It is prominently situated in the Thu Thiem New Urban Area, Thu Duc City, near the Saigon River. The Dinh Than An Khanh continues its legacy as a site of worship and a cultural anchor, successfully re-establishing the historical soul of the Thu Thiem district amid its modern, high-tech urban landscape, and serving as a point of reflection and education for the region's pioneering history.

name: Museum of Vietnamese Traditional Medicine
description: Bao tang Y hoc co truyen Viet Nam (FITO Museum) is a monumental Museum and Architectural Heritage Site from the Modern Era, serving as one of the most iconic surviving structures dedicated to Vietnamese Traditional Medicine. This site is globally renowned for its extensive Artifact Collection of over 3000 objects, its role in the Preservation of Traditional Medicine, the unique Architectural Replication of historic elements, and its status as a vital Cultural Heritage Site. The museum was the vision of Le Khac Tam, Chairman of Fito Pharma, who sought to honor and conserve the cultural and historical assets of traditional Vietnamese healing, addressing the lack of public preservation for this ancient practice. Construction began in 2004 and the museum officially opened to the public in 2007. Its primary purpose is to educate visitors about the evolution of the field from the Stone Age to the modern era, honoring great physicians like Tue Tinh and Hai Thuong Lan Ong. Located at 41 Hoang Du Khuong Street, District 10, Ho Chi Minh City, the structure spans six stories across nearly 600 square meters. Its architecture is a deliberate blend of Northern, Hue, and Cham traditional styles, with interiors entirely crafted from dark, intricately carved wood. A central feature is a replica of the entrance gate to the ancient Y Mieu Thang Long (Royal Medical Academy), originally built in 1780. The collection includes ancient tools like the dao cau and thuyen tan, some dating back 2,500 years. The FITO Museum continues to operate as a privately run, specialist museum, being the first of its kind in Vietnam. It remains a popular cultural and historical destination for both domestic and international visitors. Its enduring legacy is the successful conservation of thousands of invaluable artifacts and documents, ensuring the rich history and cultural significance of Vietnamese Traditional Medicine is accessible and honored for future generations.

name: Trung Vuong High School
description: Trung Vuong High School is a monumental Educational Institution and Architectural Heritage Site from the Post-Geneva Accords Era, serving as one of the most iconic surviving structures of Modern Vietnamese Educational Heritage. This campus is globally renowned for its enduring Educational Legacy, its status as a City-Level Architectural Relic, its preservation of French Colonial Architecture, and its history of Student Activism. Historically, the school was founded in Saigon in 1954 as a continuation of the famed Dong Khanh Girls' School of Hanoi, following the partition of Vietnam. The original purpose was to establish a premier all-girls high school, inheriting the educational ethos and personnel of the northern institution. Key figures in its establishment included the first principal, Ms. Tang Xuan An. The school later played a significant role in national events, notably a 1963 student strike protesting the Ngo Dinh Diem government's repression of Buddhism. It became co-educational after 1975. Located at 3A Nguyen Binh Khiem Street, District 1, Ho Chi Minh City, the school's total area is approximately 7,337.6 square meters. The structure is a beautiful example of French Colonial Architecture, characterized by its distinctive yellow walls, red-tiled roofs, and window designs resembling artistic arches. Construction primarily utilizes masonry and concrete, typical of structures built during the French era and its subsequent renovations. Currently, Trung Vuong High School continues to operate as a highly reputable public co-educational institution. Its architectural value has been formally recognized with a City-Level Relic classification by the Ho Chi Minh City authorities. The school's enduring legacy lies in its continuous contribution to Vietnam's educational landscape, being a major alma mater for countless notable citizens and serving as a preserved piece of urban and architectural history.

name: Temple of Saint Tran Hung Dao
description: Den tho Duc Thanh Tran Hung Dao is a monumental Temple and Historical Relic from the Mid-20th Century period, serving as one of the most iconic surviving structures of Modern Vietnamese Spiritual Culture. The shrine, built to honor the national hero Tran Hung Dao, is a powerful symbol of Patriotic Devotion and Enduring Ancestral Veneration in Southern Vietnam. This complex is critically important for its status as a City-Level Architectural and Artistic Relic, a vital Spiritual Center for the Vietnamese people, and a repository of Historical War Artifacts relating to the heroic Tran Dynasty. The temple's origins trace back to 1932, when a smaller shrine was first completed within the spacious grounds of the former Van An Pagoda to worship Tran Hung Dao (Hung Dao Dai Vuong), the 13th-century general who repelled three Mongol invasions. A significant reconstruction effort, led by the Hoi Bac Viet Tuong Te and designed by architect Nguyen Manh Bao, began in 1957 and was completed in 1958, establishing the temple's present, larger scale. The site's primary purpose has always been the veneration of the Great King, serving as a powerful focal point for national pride and spiritual belief. Located at 36 Vo Thi Sau Street, Tan Dinh Ward, District 1, Ho Chi Minh City, the temple's main building follows the traditional Vietnamese "dinh" (T-shaped) architectural plan over an area of approximately 200 square meters. The complex features three gates, with the grand main gate adorned with curved tiled roofs and dragon-phoenix motifs, only opening for major festivals. The construction primarily utilizes reinforced concrete and timber, with a roof of fish-scale tiles, reflecting a Northern Vietnamese architectural style. The courtyard contains a statue of Tran Hung Dao, while the interior features a bronze statue of the general, intricate lacquerware, wood carvings, and bas-reliefs depicting major historical events like the Battle of Bach Dang. The temple has been formally recognized as a City-Level Architectural and Artistic Relic by the Ho Chi Minh City People's Committee, securing its preservation. Annually, the site hosts large ceremonies, including the death anniversary (Gio) of Tran Hung Dao on the 20th day of the 8th lunar month, attracting thousands of visitors. The Den tho Duc Thanh Tran Hung Dao continues to be a powerful cultural landmark and a symbol of Vietnam's enduring tradition of honoring national heroes and their contributions to the country's independence.

name: Tomb of the Ministry of Military Censorship, Minister of the Tran family
description: The Mo ong Binh Bo Kiem duyet Ty, Thua vu lang ho Tran is a monumental Historical Relic and Tomb Complex from the Nguyen Dynasty period, serving as one of the rarest surviving examples of Vietnamese Imperial Heritage in the South. This site is critically important for its status as a City-Level Architectural and Artistic Relic, its display of the rare "song tan" double-tomb architecture, its link to the Imperial Bureaucratic History of the Ministry of War, and its enduring physical presence amidst a modern city. The tomb complex dates to the 10th year of King Tu Duc's reign, 1857, and is the final resting place of a Tran family official who held the post of Thua vu lang (Service Officer) in the Kiem duyet Ty (Surveillance Department) of the Binh Bo (Ministry of War), which was responsible for military and financial oversight. The tomb is a parallel burial for the official and his wife, a distinct burial custom of the era. The inscription on the stele identifies the official by his courtesy name, Don Nha. Located within a narrow alley off Tran Van Dang street in District 3, Ho Chi Minh City, the complex occupies an area of nearly 50 square meters. The structure exhibits the unique "song tan" or "nguu mieu" architectural style, featuring two parallel tombs enclosed by a low wall. The construction utilizes laterite stone and bricks, finished with a compound mortar. Key architectural elements include an incense table, a stele inscribed with Han characters, and a rear wall flanked by two stylized lotus bud pillars, though one is currently damaged. Despite the surrounding urban development, the tomb has been preserved in its original state and was officially recognized as a City-Level Architectural and Artistic Relic. It stands as a physical testament to the administrative and social structure of the Nguyen Dynasty in Southern Vietnam, representing a valuable piece of the region's funerary architecture and historical identity.

name: Memorial area of ​​Phan Chau Trinh's grave
description: The Phan Chau Trinh Tomb Memorial Area is a monumental Historical Relic and Tomb Complex from the French Colonial Era, serving as an iconic surviving structure of Vietnamese Nationalist Heritage. This complex is globally renowned for its status as a National Historical Relic, a powerful Symbol of Political Resistance, the site of a momentous National Mourning Event, and a crucial Repository of Nationalist Writings. The site was established in the wake of the death of the celebrated patriot and revolutionary leader Phan Chau Trinh (1872-1926) on March 24, 1926. The initial tomb was set up in the Go Cong Tuong Te cemetery with land donated by a wealthy landowner, and the funeral was a massive public demonstration of national solidarity, funded by the people—an act commemorated on the tomb's facade with the inscription "Quoc dan dong phung lap." The first temple was constructed in District 1 in 1930 by the Central Region Friendship Association before being relocated and rebuilt beside the grave in 1993. The entire commemorative complex spans approximately 2,500 square meters and is situated at 9 Phan Thuc Duyen Street, Ward 4, Tan Binh District, Ho Chi Minh City. Architectural features include a large bust of Phan Chau Trinh and a modern temple, the latter built to simulate the classic octagonal foundation and three-tiered roof of the original Da Kao temple. The tomb itself is now a wide, house-style grave with a tiled roof, flanked by a large stele engraved with a biography written by Huynh Thuc Khang in 1926. The adjacent memorial house preserves and displays his artifacts, including his political writings and personal belongings like a preserved suit. Recognized as a National Historical Relic by the Ministry of Culture and Information in 1994, the site remains a vital pilgrimage point. It continues to uphold Phan Chau Trinh’s enduring legacy and political philosophy of "Uplift the people's spirit, enlighten the people's intellect, and improve the people's livelihood.

name: Tan Ky Temple - Ong Bon Temple
description: Mieu Tan Ky - Mieu Ong Bon is a monumental Religious Worship Site from the French Colonial Era, serving as an enduring cultural center for the Chinese-Vietnamese (Hoa) Community. This temple, over 140 years old, is globally renowned for its deep roots in Community Solidarity, its practice of Traditional Fukien Worship, its status as a local Cultural Relic, and its vital role as a contemporary Charity Hub. The temple was established in the late 19th century by the local Hoa population, particularly those with Fukien lineage, to honor Ông Bổn (Phuoc Duc Chanh Than), a protector deity revered as the "Ancestor God" or "Righteous Spirit of Blessings and Virtue." Its original purpose was to provide a spiritual and social gathering place, cementing ethnic ties and offering mutual aid to the community in the Tan Binh area, a practice common in Saigon-Cholon. Originally, the structure featured classic Sino-Vietnamese temple architecture, utilizing durable materials like fired brick, traditional yin-yang roof tiles, and elaborate carvings of dragons and mythical creatures, reflecting the distinctive artistry of the era. Its address is a quiet location deep within a narrow alley at 481/13 Truong Chinh, Ward 14, Tan Binh District, with a geographical location approximated at 10.8 degrees North, 106.66 degrees East. While it holds the status of a city-level cultural relic, the temple has undergone substantial recent non-specialized renovations, leading to a significant alteration of its original architectural appearance. Despite the physical changes, the Mieu Tan Ky - Mieu Ong Bon continues its profound legacy as a functioning site of worship, communal gathering, and charitable activity, securing its historical importance as a resilient spiritual anchor for the local Hoa population.

name: Southern Air Force Museum
description:
The Southern Air Force Museum is a monumental Military Museum and Heritage Site from the Post-Reunification period, serving as a vital repository of the Vietnam People's Air Force history. It is a critical component of Ho Chi Minh City's cultural landscape, directly preserving the heroism and development of the nation's aviation forces. The museum is renowned for its Historical Preservation, showcasing the nation's Military Heritage, serving as a crucial Educational Resource for the youth, and functioning as a quiet Memorial Site for fallen airmen.

Established in 1989 under Military Region 7, the museum’s primary purpose was to document the historical contributions of the Vietnam Air Force, particularly in the southern region. Its collections vividly recount the unit's formation, significant victories—including images and artifacts from the 12-day-and-night air campaign against US forces—and the crucial development of the Air Force Division 370. The exhibits highlight the sacrifices and strategic triumphs of various generations of air force personnel who defended the country. The site is located at 87 Thang Long Street, Tan Binh District, positioned near the Tan Son Nhat Airport. It features a modern, solemn architectural design across two indoor floors and a significant outdoor display area. The open-air section showcases a collection of iconic aircraft, including the Mi-24, MiG-21, F-5, and UH-1 Huey helicopters, while the interior houses extensive images, documents, and smaller artifacts. Its general geographic location is approximately 10.811 degrees North, 106.666 degrees East. Currently, the museum operates as an active, free-entry public educational institution, often hosting students and researchers. Its legacy lies in its continuous effort to educate the public about the Air Force's role in national defense and construction, solidifying its place as an invaluable source for the study of Vietnamese military history.

name: Hoang Van Thu Park
description: Hoang Van Thu Park is a monumental Public Urban Park from the Post-Reunification period, serving as a critical surviving element of Ho Chi Minh City's Modern Urban Heritage. The park is globally renowned for its role as the Green Lung of Tan Binh District, its function as a Memorial Site honoring a national hero, and its position as a central Community and Recreation Hub. Its historical roots trace back to before 1975, when the land was part of the US military's 3rd Field Hospital, primarily serving as a helicopter landing pad. Following the liberation of the South, the land came under the management of Military Region 7 before being designated for public use. The park's official establishment and inauguration occurred on March 28, 1989, as part of the city's plan to create green spaces for its residents. It was named in honor of Hoang Van Thu (1909–1944), an unyielding Vietnamese revolutionary leader and a key figure in the Indochinese Communist Party, whose memory is preserved through this vital public space.
