The park encompasses an area of approximately 10.65 hectares (106,500 square meters) and features a unique triangular geometric design, bounded by the major thoroughfares of Hoang Van Thu, Phan Dinh Giot, and Tran Quoc Hoan streets. Key features include an extensive tree canopy, jogging paths, a pedestrian overpass, a small lake used for recreational fishing, and a dedicated children's play area. Its geographic location is noted by the coordinates 10.8012 degrees North, 106.6643 degrees East. Hoang Van Thu Park is currently an active public amenity, operating as a crucial environmental buffer against urban pollution and a center for social and physical well-being. It is managed by the Tan Binh District Public Services Company and is constantly being upgraded to meet the community's needs. The park’s enduring legacy lies in its dual role: a functional green space for modern city life and a quiet, historical monument that subtly connects contemporary residents to the nation's revolutionary past.

name: Phu Xuan Communal House, Nha Be
description: Dinh Phu Xuan Nha Be is a monumental Vietnamese Communal Temple from the early 19th Century period, serving as a significant surviving structure of the Southern Vietnamese Folk Religion and Local Worship Culture. This sacred site is locally renowned for its role as a Worshipping Center for local Deities and National Heroes, its status as a City-Level Architectural Relic, and its function as a vital Community Spiritual Anchor. Established around the year 1800 during the initial settlement of the southern region, Dinh Phu Xuan served as a communal spiritual center for the people of Phu Xuan commune. Its original purpose was to honor the Thanh Hoang Bon Can (Guardian God of the Village) and the spirits of the pioneers, establishing a moral and religious framework for the new community in the Nha Be region. The architectural style is traditional Vietnamese, typically featuring a wooden frame structure with a tiled roof, reflecting the construction techniques and materials common in the early 19th century. The complex is noted for its spacious grounds, abundant green trees, and its advantageous position situated by the Rach Doi River, which was historically important for local transport. The physical layout, though likely subject to later renovations, preserves the fundamental design of a Southern Vietnamese Dinh, with distinct areas for communal meetings and ritual ceremonies. The Dinh was officially recognized as a City-level Architectural and Art Relic by the People's Committee of Ho Chi Minh City in 2012, a designation that provides legal protection for its continued preservation. It remains an active place of worship and a hub for traditional festivals, continuing its legacy as a strong symbol of local identity, historical resilience, and a repository of the region’s traditional spiritual beliefs.

name: Mausoleum of Ong Thuy Tuong
description: Lăng Ông Thuy Tuong, or the Mausoleum of the Whale General, is a monumental Coastal Religious Shrine from the Nguyen Dynasty Era, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Southern Vietnamese Fishing Culture and Nam Hai Folk Religion. This sacred site is locally renowned for its unique Whale Bone Repository, its status as a City-Level Historical Relic, and its connection to the National Intangible Cultural Heritage Nghinh Ông Festival, solidifying its role as a vital Community Spiritual Anchor. The shrine’s origins date back to the mid-18th to 19th centuries, during the time of the Nguyen Lords, when its predecessor, the Mieu Than Bien (Sea God Shrine), was established at the flourishing Can Gio trading port. Its central purpose is the worship of Nam Hai Dai Tuong Quan (the Great General of the Southern Sea), a revered name for Ca Ong (the Whale Deity or spirit whale), who is believed to protect fishermen from the sea's dangers. After several moves, the mausoleum was relocated to its current position on Duyen Hai Street in Can Thanh Town in 1952. Architecturally, the complex adheres to the traditional style of a Southern Vietnamese communal house and mausoleum. Its most distinguishing feature is the Ngoc Cot (Jade Bone), a fully reconstructed skeleton of a whale, measuring 12 meters long, which is preserved and displayed in three large glass cabinets, a testament to the community's deep-seated devotion to the Whale Deity. The site was recognized as a City-level Architectural and Art Relic in 2012 and continues to draw pilgrims and visitors, particularly during the annual Nghinh Ong Festival (Whale Welcoming Festival), a major cultural event and a National Intangible Cultural Heritage. The Dinh remains a powerful symbol of the coastal community's resilience, faith, and maritime traditions.

name: Dinh Duong Van Hanh
description: Dinh Duong Van Hanh is a monumental Communal Shrine and Historical Monument from the Late 19th Century, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Southern Vietnamese Resistance Heritage. This site is locally renowned for its Local Hero Worship, its deep association with the Anti-French Resistance, its official status as a City-Level Historical Relic, and its enduring role as a Community Spiritual Center. The shrine is dedicated to Duong Van Hanh, a local official and a devoted logistics officer for the anti-French resistance leader Truong Dinh. In 1863, during the early French occupation, Duong Van Hanh was captured in the Ly Nhon strategic zone (now Can Gio District) and subjected to brutal torture by French forces to reveal Truong Dinh's location. He refused to betray his commander and was subsequently executed by beheading at the bank of the Soai Rap River, earning him the revered local moniker Than Khong Dau (The Headless Deity). The local community secretly retrieved his headless remains, provided a proper burial, and established this Dinh (communal house) to officially honor him as their Tutelary Spirit (Thanh Hoang) for his sacrifice and protective influence over the village. The original Dinh was repeatedly moved due to war damage and riverbank erosion, notably relocating to its present address on Duong Van Hanh Street, Ly Thai Buu Hamlet, Ly Nhon Commune in 1978. While the building has seen several relocations and subsequent renovations, it maintains the traditional architectural elements of a Southern Vietnamese communal house, with a focus on the main sanctuary dedicated to the hero's altar. The Dinh continues to be an active, integral part of the Ly Nhon community's spiritual life, maintaining its City-level Historical Relic status and preserving the powerful memory of loyalty and the pioneering spirit of resistance in Southern Vietnam.

name: Binh Khanh Communal House - Tomb of Sage Tran Quang Dao
description: Dinh Binh Khanh - Mo Tien hien Tran Quang Dao is a monumental Communal House and Pioneer's Tomb from the Late 19th Century, serving as an iconic surviving structure of the Southern Vietnamese Pioneering Culture. This complex is locally renowned for its Pioneering Heritage, its role as a Spiritual Protectorate, its embodiment of Local Hero Worship, and its importance for Communal Cohesion within the Can Gio region. Its history is intrinsically linked to the figure of Tran Quang Dao, a tien hien (precursor) who, with his mother, was instrumental in the reclamation and settlement of the Xoai Rap river mouth area during the early decades of the 19th century. After successfully gathering a population, Tran Quang Dao petitioned for the establishment of the Binh Khanh village, subsequently serving as its thon truong (village chief) until his passing around 1886. The core purpose of the site was to establish a spiritual and social center, where the community could honor Tran Quang Dao as their Thanh Hoang (Tutelary Spirit) for his foundational merits and protective influence, including a local legend where his strength purportedly kept dangerous animals like tigers and crocodiles away from the settlement. Architecturally, the compound represents a traditional Vietnamese communal structure, housing the Dinh's main worship areas and the distinct, revered tomb of the pioneer, the gravestone of which is inscribed "Tien hien Tran Quang Dao chi vi." This historical landmark is located in the Binh Khanh Commune of Can Gio District, Ho Chi Minh City, placing it in a vital, estuary-adjacent position approximately around 10.59 N, 106.87 E. The site remains an active spiritual center, preserving the memory of the region's founding and continuing to host community rituals, thereby maintaining its status as a significant local Architectural and Cultural Relic of Southern Vietnam.

name: Phu Lac Communal House
description: Dinh Phu Lac is a monumental Communal House and Worship Center from the Nguyen Dynasty Era, serving as an iconic structure of the Southern Vietnamese Gia Dinh Culture. This sacred site is historically renowned for its Royal Recognition, its pivotal role as a Revolutionary Base during the resistance, its designation as an Architectural Heritage site, and its enduring importance for Communal Worship. The Dinh, like many traditional village communal houses, was established in the 19th century with the core purpose of honoring the local tutelary spirit (Thanh Hoang) and other ancestors, thereby unifying the spiritual and social life of the local Phong Phu community. Its historical significance was formally documented in 1852 when it received an official Imperial Decree from King Tu Duc, an invaluable cultural artifact still preserved at the site. Beyond its religious functions, Dinh Phu Lac served as a secret staging ground and meeting point for resistance activities against French colonial forces. Architecturally, it is a traditional wooden temple built on a spacious riverside location in what was once the heart of the Binh Chanh district. The structure itself is a testament to the simple yet robust Southern Vietnamese communal style, centered around a main worship hall that protects the historical decree and ceremonial objects. The temple is located in Phong Phu Commune, Binh Chanh District, Ho Chi Minh City, with coordinates placing it near 10.706 N, 106.602 E. Dinh Phu Lac was officially recognized in 2007 as a local Architectural Heritage Site. It continues to function as a vital spiritual anchor, hosting annual traditional festivals and preserving the historical memory of the Binh Chanh region's cultural and patriotic past.

name: Binh Truong Communal House
description: Dinh Binh Truong is a monumental Communal House and Worship Center from the Nguyen Dynasty Era (19th Century), serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Southern Vietnamese Gia Dinh Culture. The Dinh is globally renowned for its Historical Significance, status as a City-Level Architectural Relic, role as a Revolutionary Base, and its enduring cultural importance through the traditional Ky Yen Festival. Established around 1818, its original purpose was to honor the village tutelary spirit, Thanh Hoang Ban Canh, a practice central to the spiritual and social life of the Binh Truong village community in the historic Tan Long district. Its historical importance was cemented in 1852 when it received a Royal Edict (Sac phong) from King Tu Duc, formally recognizing the spirit. In the 20th century, the site secretly supported the independence movement. The architectural style adheres to the traditional Southern Vietnamese Dinh model, featuring a complex of interconnected structures, including a Main Hall (Chinh Dien) and an Assembly House (Nha Hoi). Constructed primarily with traditional materials like timber for the load-bearing framework and tiled roofs, it showcases high-art wood carvings, ancient ceremonial objects, and the original King Tu Duc Sac phong. It is located in what is now Ho Chi Minh City, being formally recognized for its value. On February 1, 2005, Dinh Binh Truong was officially recognized as a City-level Architectural and Artistic Relic by Ho Chi Minh City. It continues to function as a vital spiritual and cultural center, hosting annual traditional rites such as the Ky Yen festival and preserving priceless Han-Nom texts and historical artifacts for future generations.

name: An Phu Communal House
description: Dinh An Phu is a monumental Communal House and Historical Relic from the Vietnamese Resistance Era, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Southern Vietnamese Gia Dinh Culture. This site is globally renowned for its role as a crucial Base of Revolutionary Activity, a Historical Witness to key national events, and an enduring Spiritual Anchor for the local community, officially recognized as a City-level historical relic. Historically, the Dinh originated as a traditional communal house for the people of the An Phu area to worship the village guardian spirit and various local deities, a common practice for community cohesion in Southern Vietnam. However, during the periods of resistance against the French and American forces, the Dinh evolved into a pivotal center for the independence movement, serving as a secret base for the Viet Minh and playing a strategic role in the 1968 Tet Offensive and the Ho Chi Minh Campaign in 1975. The complex occupies an area of approximately 2,500 square meters and is situated in the An Phu Ward of Thu Duc City, Ho Chi Minh City. While its precise architectural history is typical of a Southern-style Dinh, featuring timber-framed construction with tiled roofs, its physical location holds significant cultural weight as a historical landmark. Today, Dinh An Phu is preserved under the care of a local Management Board, having been recognized as a Historical Relic by Ho Chi Minh City in 2006, ensuring its continued legacy as both a sacred site and a profound memorial to the spirit of national defense, with the annual Ky Yen worship ceremony continuing to uphold its role in community life.

name: Minh Dang Quang Court
description: Phap Vien Minh Dang Quang is a monumental Buddhist Dharma Institute from the Modern Era of Post-War Vietnam, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Vietnamese Khat Si Tradition. The temple complex is globally renowned for its status as the Organizational Center of the Khat Si sect, its massive and harmonious Architectural Ensemble, its role as a crucial Spiritual Haven in Ho Chi Minh City, and holding multiple National Records for its stupas. Historically, the Phap Vien was founded in 1968 by the Most Venerable Phap Su Giac Nhien, the first Head of the Mendicant Order IV, with the primary purpose of establishing a permanent, sustainable center for dharma propagation to serve the rapidly expanding Vietnamese Mendicant Sangha. The compound is situated on approximately 27,500 to 37,490 square meters along the arterial Vo Nguyen Giap street (formerly Xa Lo Ha Noi) in the Binh Trung area of Thu Duc City. The central structure is a colossal, three-story main hall, measuring 40 meters wide and 70 meters long, flanked by a quartet of impressive Bao Thap (Stupas). Two front stupas are octagonal, reaching 37 meters high with nine stories, while two rear ones are tetragonal, rising to 49 meters with thirteen stories. This feature established its record as the tịnh xá (monastery) with the four largest stupas in Vietnam. Today, Phap Vien Minh Dang Quang remains a vibrant and active pilgrimage site and the principal head-temple of the Khat Si lineage, representing an enduring legacy of distinct Vietnamese Buddhist architectural innovation and the continued practice of the mendicant lifestyle in the urban landscape.

name: Phuoc Long Pagoda (Thu Duc)
description: The Phuoc Long Pagoda, also known as Chua Chau Doc 3, is a monumental Buddhist Temple from the Modern Era of Post-War Vietnam, serving as a unique and enduring expression of Southern Vietnamese Buddhist Culture. This sacred site is widely recognized for its Unique River Island Location, impressive Traditional Wooden Architecture, expansive Outdoor Sculpture Garden, and practice of Syncretic Worship with the Lady Chua Xu shrine. The pagoda’s origins trace back to a small, thatched hermitage established on the Ba Sang Islet in the 1960s. Venerable Thich Nhat Phat began living there before 1975, and after a period away, he returned in 1993 to oversee its revitalization. The major construction of the current temple structure, built over two years starting in 2009, was a large-scale project aimed at creating a dedicated and durable center for Northern Buddhist practice and pilgrimage in the region. Spanning approximately 1.5 hectares on an islet in the Dong Nai River, its isolation creates a serene spiritual oasis. The two-story main sanctuary is a masterpiece of traditional Vietnamese wood construction, featuring over 2,000 cubic meters of cam xe wood. Skilled artisans from Hue were commissioned for the meticulous carvings on the gilded rafters and columns. The grounds feature a distinctive outdoor sanctuary with hundreds of statues, including a 10-meter-long Reclining Buddha and a separate, important shrine to Ba Chua Xu (Lady Chua Xu), which is why it is often called Chau Doc 3. Today, the pagoda remains an active spiritual sanctuary and a major pilgrimage destination, particularly during Buddhist holidays. Its legacy is tied to the preservation of traditional religious architecture and its role as a spiritual haven, offering a tranquil escape and a cultural link to the revered Lady Chua Xu tradition.

name: Nam Thien Nhat Tru Pagoda
description: The Nam Thien Nhat Tru Pagoda is a monumental Religious Edifice from the Post-War Period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Southern Vietnamese Buddhist Heritage. This sacred site is globally renowned for its Unique Architecture, status as a faithful Architectural Replica, its deep Spiritual Significance, and enduring role as a tranquil Cultural Landmark. Its history begins with the Venerable Monk Thich Tri Dung, who initiated its construction in 1958 with the singular purpose of replicating the famed 11th-century One Pillar Pagoda of Hanoi in the South. This act was a profound spiritual and cultural gesture, ensuring the architectural and religious legacy of the original landmark persisted for the Buddhist community. Architecturally, the most distinguishing feature is the Lien Hoa Dai (Lotus Flower Platform) main sanctuary, which rests upon a single, massive concrete pillar, built to faithfully recreate the unique design of its Northern counterpart. Located at 100 Dang Van Bi in the Binh Tho Ward of Thu Duc City, the elevated structure of wood and concrete materials is designed to evoke the imagery of a lotus blossom rising from the water, a significant Buddhist symbol. Today, the pagoda remains an active place of worship and a tranquil Spiritual Sanctuary that attracts both domestic and foreign visitors. Its legacy is not only architectural but also cultural, serving as a powerful, tangible link between the Buddhist traditions of Northern and Southern Vietnam and an enduring symbol of spiritual purity in Ho Chi Minh City.

name: Thu Duc Parish
description: The Giao Xu Thu Duc is a monumental Religious Edifice and Parish Church from the Late 19th Century Colonial Period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Vietnamese Catholic Heritage. This venerable complex is globally renowned for its Gothic Architecture, its role as a Historical Landmark, its deep Religious Significance, and its function as a vital Community Anchor. The parish’s origins trace back to the establishment of the Ho Dao Phong Phu in 1879, intended to serve local Catholics who previously had to travel great distances for Mass. Construction of the main church began around 1889, featuring a bell cast a year prior in 1878. Key development phases included the addition of the two side wings in the 1930s by priests like Father Petro Tha and Father Gioan Baotixita Doan, forming the traditional cross shape. Father Anre Le Van Quyen then oversaw the painting and final completion in 1938. Architecturally, the church embodies the Gothic style, defined by symmetrical, arched column-rows within the sanctuary and a prominent bell tower. The structure itself covers an area of 808 square meters within a spacious, green compound spanning 6,468 square meters, located at 51 Vo Van Ngan, Linh Chieu Ward, Thu Duc City, Ho Chi Minh City. Having undergone its most recent major renovation in 2013 to preserve its unique architecture, the church currently functions as a central religious hub. Its legacy lies in its status as the oldest church in the Thu Duc area, witnessing over a century of development and actively serving a large and devoted congregation with multiple active societies and choirs.

name: Ao Dai Museum
description: The Bao Tang Ao Dai is a monumental Cultural Heritage Museum and Landmark from the Contemporary Era, serving as the most iconic surviving structure dedicated to the Vietnamese Cultural Heritage. This complex is globally renowned for its Preservation of Ao Dai, its role as a Community Anchor, its showcase of Traditional Vietnamese Architecture, and its crucial Educational Programs. Historically, the museum was conceived and initiated by famous artist and designer Si Hoang to safeguard and celebrate the traditional Vietnamese dress, which has evolved through centuries of design. The original purpose was to bridge the gap between Vietnam's rich cultural past and its modern identity, ensuring the Ao Dai's legacy endures across generations. The museum, officially opened in 2014, serves as a repository displaying hundreds of traditional Ao Dai designs spanning various historical periods, from the Ao Dai Tu Than to the modern versions. Architecturally, the museum occupies a vast, nearly 20,000 square meter natural space in Thu Duc City (approximate coordinates 10.8 N, 106.8 E). Its unique design masterfully combines the traditional imprints of the Southern river region and the classical style of Quang Nam communal houses. Key features are the unique wooden architectural clusters, meticulously restored by artisan Kim Bong, and the tranquil surrounding complex of ponds and gardens, creating a profound sense of harmony. The museum's enduring legacy is its status as a premier cultural institution, actively promoting the Ao Dai as an integral part of national identity through comprehensive exhibitions and interactive workshops, ensuring the garment's significance continues to inspire artists and visitors worldwide.

name: That Phu Thien Hau Palace
description: The That Phu Thien Hau Cung is a monumental Chinese Assembly Hall and Temple from the Nguyen Dynasty and French Colonial Era, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Chinese-Vietnamese Merchant Civilization. This complex is globally renowned for its Religious Significance, its role as a Community Anchor, a Historical Economic Nexus, and a masterwork of Southern Chinese Architecture in Vietnam. The term "That Phu" (Seven Congregations) denotes the initial union of seven regional Chinese guilds—including Guangdong, Fujian, and Chaozhou—that collectively established and maintained this center in the Cholon district of Saigon. Its history, dating back to the 18th and 19th centuries, places it as the spiritual and political heart of the Chinese diaspora, primarily dedicated to the worship of Thien Hau (Mazu), the revered Goddess of the Sea, who was essential for protecting the seafarers and merchants who founded the community. The architecture is a classical example of Southern Chinese temple design, typically featuring a complex layout of interconnected halls (tu tru structure) and courtyards, built with traditional wood and stone. The roofs are particularly notable, adorned with intricately carved ceramic mosaics of dragons, mythological figures, and the eight immortals, all covered with yin-yang tiles. Although parts of the original complex associated with the General Chinese Merchant Association were dismantled or destroyed in the late 20th century, the spiritual and cultural legacy endures. Today, its traditions are actively maintained in the surrounding Cholon area (approximate coordinates 10.75 N, 106.65 E), preserving the profound cultural identity and historical significance of the Hoa community's centuries-old presence in Southern Vietnam.

name: An Hoi Communal House
description: The Dinh An Hoi is a monumental Traditional Communal House (Dinh) from the Nguyen Dynasty period, established in the mid-19th century, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Southern Vietnamese Folk Culture and Architecture. This sacred site is globally renowned as a Provincial-level Historical-Cultural Relic, a Center of Community Worship, a host for Major Annual Festivals (such as Ky Yen), and a quintessential example of Mekong Delta Architectural Style. Historically, the Dinh was first established by a local official, Huynh Van Sac, and received Imperial recognition (Sac Than) in 1846 during the reign of Emperor Thieu Tri. It was originally built to worship the Village Deity (Thanh Hoang) of the merged An Hoi, An Duc, Phu Khuong, and My Hoa villages, serving as the spiritual, political, and cultural nexus for the local community. The Dinh’s architecture follows the traditional “Nhat” (One) shape, characteristic of Nguyen Dynasty communal houses. Its structure uses precious wood in a xuyen trinh style, comprising three main bays and two wings (ba gian, hai chai). The roof is covered with yin-yang tiles and features elaborately carved ceramic statuettes of Bat Tien Du Hoi (Eight Immortals) and the luong long chau nhat (two dragons flanking the sun) motif, inspired by the ancient river civilization. The complex spans approximately 1,150 square meters and is currently located on Nguyen Dinh Chieu Street in Ben Tre City (approximate coordinates 10.39 N, 106.38 E). The Dinh An Hoi was formally recognized as a Provincial-level Historical-Cultural Relic in 2014. It continues to function as a vibrant spiritual site, actively organizing traditional rituals and annual festivals that preserve the deep-rooted customs and beliefs of the Mekong Delta's agricultural and river-faring people. The Dinh's enduring legacy is its role in maintaining cultural identity across generations.

name: Sa Tan Temple
description: The Sa Tan Mieu is a monumental Folk Religious Shrine from the Late 18th/Early 19th Century period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Southern Vietnamese and Chinese-Vietnamese Heritage. This ancient site, often called the Floating Temple, is globally renowned as a City-level Architectural Relic, a Spiritual Center, a powerful focus for River Deities Worship, and a unique example of Viet-Hoa Architectural Fusion. The shrine's origins are rooted in a local legend from the old Gia Dinh province, specifically the Ben Cat River area. Lore recounts that an unnamed fisherman, Ong Chai, was unable to catch any fish one cold winter day but instead hauled a strange statue—believed to be Ba Thuy Te, the Water Goddess—from the river. He established a small shrine to enshrine the statue, and the site became a sacred point for those praying for safe passage and prosperity on the water. Following a major renovation in 1955, the site was officially renamed Sa Tan Mieu Ky Thanh Thuy Long Cung. Located on the banks of the Vam Thuat River in Go Vap District, the temple occupies a modest area of approximately 150 square meters. The complex uniquely combines the characteristics of a traditional Southern Vietnamese communal house with the ornate decorative elements of Chinese temples. Its walls, columns, and ceilings are meticulously carved and covered in multi-colored ceramic and porcelain fragments, giving the shrine a distinctively bright and elaborate appearance. The structure's most unique physical feature is its location, seemingly isolated by the river, with approximate coordinates of 10.850 N and 106.670 E. Sa Tan Mieu was officially recognized as a City-level Architectural and Artistic Relic by Ho Chi Minh City in November 2020. It continues to be an actively visited site, drawing pilgrims and tourists who seek blessings from Thuy Long Cung Thanh Mau and pay respects to the founding fisherman. The shrine’s enduring legacy is its role as a living memory of old Saigon-Gia Dinh, quietly preserving the spiritual and architectural history of its merged communities.

name: Sac Tu Tap Phuoc Pagoda
description: The Sac Tu Tap Phuoc Pagoda is a monumental Buddhist Temple from the Early Nguyen Dynasty period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Southern Vietnamese Buddhist Heritage. This ancient pagoda is globally renowned as a City-level Historical Relic, a Spiritual Center, a beacon of the Northern Buddhism lineage, and a profound Architectural Landmark in the historic Gia Dinh region. Historically, the temple was founded around the mid-18th century by the venerable Buddhist monk Toan Tanh – Chanh Dac with the purpose of establishing a center for worship and monastic training for the growing community in the South. Its official designation as Sac Tu Tap Phuoc Tu (Imperially Bestowed Tập Phước Temple) was decreed in 1802 by Emperor Gia Long, cementing its significance within the imperial and religious landscape of Vietnam. The site continues to serve its original spiritual function, historically organizing courses for monks and lay practitioners. Architecturally, the pagoda is a fine example of a traditional co tu (ancient temple), classified as a municipal-level artistic and architectural relic. It is located at 233 Phan Van Tri Street, Binh Thanh District, Ho Chi Minh City, with geographic coordinates approximately 10.8127 degrees North and 106.6947 degrees East. The grounds include stupas housing the ashes of former revered abbots from the Lam Te Zen school lineage, such as Hoa Thuong Phuoc Tuong, Hue Thanh, and Hoang Tri. Sac Tu Tap Phuoc Pagoda was formally recognized as a City-level Architectural and Artistic Relic by the Ho Chi Minh City People's Committee in December 2005. It remains an active and influential center for the Buddhist community, ensuring the preservation of its religious traditions and architectural legacy for modern generations.

name: Long Thanh Pagoda (Binh Tan)
description: The Long Thanh Pagoda, known as To Dinh Long Thanh Co Tu, is a monumental Buddhist Temple from the Early Nguyen Dynasty period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Southern Vietnamese Buddhist Heritage. This ancient temple is globally renowned as a City-level Historical Relic, a Southern Famous Ancient Pagoda, a Spiritual Center, and a former Revolutionary Base during the anti-colonial wars. It was first established in the year Canh Dan (1740) by the revered Zen Master To Dat – Tri Tam, a figure of the 36th generation of the Lam Te Zen school, with the primary purpose of serving as a central place of worship and monastic practice for the local community. Further testament to its early history is the Great Bronze Bell, a significant artifact that was cast in 1797, thanks to a donation from Ms. Ma Thi Nhan. The pagoda also played a pivotal, secretive role during the Anti-French and Anti-American Resistance, contributing significantly to the historical record of the area. The complex is situated on a spacious 1.2-hectare plot of land at 1756 Tinh Lo 10, Tan Tao Ward, Binh Tan District, Ho Chi Minh City. It maintains the traditional architectural layout of a Southern Vietnamese temple, though it has undergone major restorations in the 20th century. The main sanctuary, or Chanh Dien, is characterized by a simple yet solemn arrangement. It prominently features a large, historical Central Buddha statue made of bronze, weighing 1,600 kilograms, which is believed to date back to the pagoda's founding era. Additional features include a formal Tam Quan gate and a Quan Am (Avalokiteshvara) platform added during the 1990s. Long Thanh Pagoda was officially recognized as a City-level Historical Relic by the Ho Chi Minh City People's Committee in October 2005. It remains an active and vital religious center, currently housing the office for the Buddhist Committee of Binh Tan District, thereby ensuring its enduring legacy as a spiritual anchor and a cultural landmark.

name: Dinh Binh Tri Dong
description: The Dinh Binh Tri Dong is a monumental Communal Temple from the Pre-French Colonial Era, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Southern Vietnamese Communal Heritage. This communal house is globally renowned for its designation as an Architectural Art Relic, its historical role as a Revolutionary Base, a Martyrs' Memorial Site, and its enduring function as a Community Worship Center. Established by the local ancestors a very long time ago, potentially over 150 years, its original purpose was to worship the Village Guardian Spirit (Thanh Hoang Bon Canh) and act as the administrative and social hub for the Binh Tri Dong village. During the 20th century, particularly the Anti-American Resistance, the Dinh became a critical, secret base for revolutionary soldiers, leading to significant events, including the heroic sacrifice of many combatants during the 1968 Tet Offensive. A memorial stele now stands on the grounds to honor these individuals. The Dinh is located at 2 Le Dinh Can Street, Binh Tri Dong A Ward, Binh Tan District, Ho Chi Minh City. While it has undergone restorations over time, it maintains the traditional architectural style of a Southern Vietnamese communal house, characterized by a multi-structure layout with a main sanctuary (Chanh Dien) and likely featuring dark wood, tiled roofs, and intricate carvings that reflect the region's cultural aesthetics. The Dinh Binh Tri Dong was formally recognized as a City-level Architectural Art Relic by the Ho Chi Minh City People's Committee in November 2020. It continues to be an active religious and cultural site, attracting visitors and locals, and plays a vital role in local education, preserving the historical memory of the community and the sacrifices made during wartime.

name: Binh Thuan Parish (Binh Tan)
description: The Giao Xu Binh Thuan is a monumental Catholic Religious Complex from the Post-War/Modern Era, serving as an enduring spiritual anchor for the Vietnamese Catholic Community. This site is globally renowned for its role as an active Pastoral Center, a resilient Community Heritage Site, and a dedicated nexus for Diaconal Service. The parish traces its formal origins to 1966, a critical period that saw the expansion of religious communities in the greater Saigon area, initially established to provide a spiritual home for a growing population. It is dedicated to its patron, Our Lady of the Rosary (Duc Me Man Coi). While the exact details of its original construction are less documented, the community continued to develop over the decades, with 1996 potentially marking a major milestone in its physical or canonical development. The complex is prominently situated at 722 Tan Ky, Tan Quy, Binh Hung Hoa, Binh Tan District, Ho Chi Minh City. Its modern architecture is generally functional, built from standard urban materials to accommodate a large and active congregation, and features a bell tower and main sanctuary designed for regular, large-scale liturgical celebrations. Today, Giao Xu Binh Thuan remains a flourishing part of the Archdiocese of Saigon (Tong Giao Phan Sai Gon), continually welcoming new parish priests and maintaining a lively schedule of services and community events. Its enduring legacy is its commitment to both faith and local community, as evidenced by its celebrations and ongoing pastoral activities.

name: St. Paul Parish (Binh Tan)
description: The Giao Xu Thanh Phaolo (Binh Tan) is a monumental Catholic Religious Complex from the Mid-20th Century/Modern Era, serving as a vital anchor for the Vietnamese Catholic Community. This site is globally renowned for its active role as a Migrant Community Center, its dedication to Diaconal and Charitable Service, and its status as a significant Urban Spiritual Sanctuary in the developing Binh Tan district. Historically, the parish traces its origins to 1961 when Father Giuse Vu Suy Ba established a small chapel and camp to serve a growing community, a response necessitated by the socio-political changes of the era. The parish was officially recognized by the Archdiocese of Saigon on July 3, 1962. A permanent, earlier church structure was consecrated in 1969 in the Phu Lam area. The current, larger church complex, located in the An Lac Binh Tri Dong residential area, was initiated on March 19, 1999, under the leadership of Father Phaolo Pham Trung Dong, to accommodate the rapidly expanding congregation. The current building stands prominently at 280 Vanh Dai Trong, in the Binh Tan District of Ho Chi Minh City, featuring a style typical of large Modern Catholic Architecture designed for functional, large-scale worship. Today, the parish continues to serve its community of approximately 4,500 parishioners, alongside a transient population of 6,000 to 7,000 Catholic migrants who have relocated to the area for work. Its legacy is defined by its social mission, offering charity classes, a free medicine program, and other social welfare services, reinforcing its pivotal role as a welcoming spiritual and social hub for internal migrants in the city.

name: Thien An Parish
description: The Thien An Monastery is a monumental Catholic Religious Complex from the Mid-20th Century Post-Colonial Period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Vietnamese Benedictine Order. This vast complex is globally renowned for its unique Eastern-Western Architectural Fusion, its profound status as a Spiritual and Contemplative Sanctuary, and its tranquil location as a Historical Pine Forest Retreat. Historically, the site was founded by the Benedictine order's Father Dom Romain Guillaume in 1940, who relocated the initial monastic effort from Da Lat, establishing the complex in Hue with the purpose of creating a permanent home for the Benedictine community in Vietnam. Located approximately 10 kilometers from Hue's city center, the Monastery sits atop a secluded hill within a sprawling pine forest, a geographical feature that lends itself to its name, meaning "Heaven's Peace." Its physical presence is defined by a distinctive blend of styles, with the central chapel featuring Gothic architectural elements—typical of Catholic churches—yet overlaid with a secondary yin-yang tiled roof and motifs reminiscent of the traditional Asian Tam Quan gate. The compound includes a prominent seven-storey tower and carefully manicured grounds arranged in a style similar to Vietnamese temple gardens, reflecting its unique aesthetic synthesis. Today, the Thien An Monastery remains an active spiritual center, maintaining its original monastic purpose while also serving as a popular cultural and tourist destination for those seeking tranquility and historical exploration in the Thua Thien Hue province (approximate latitude and longitude 16.3 N, 107.5 E).

name: Tan Thai Son Parish
description: Giao Xu Tan Thai Son is a monumental Catholic Parish Complex from the Mid-20th Century Post-War Era, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the North Vietnamese Catholic Migrant Culture. This prominent complex is globally renowned for its history as a Community Resettlement Hub, its vast Community Outreach Programs, its central role as a Major Spiritual Center, and its unique Blended Architectural Style. The parish's origins trace back to the period following the 1954 Geneva Accords, when Father Domin Tran Khac Thieu led Catholic families from Tien Hai, Thai Binh Diocese, to settle in the southern region. The community established the Tan Thai Son Resettlement Camp, and in 1957, Bishop Simon Hoa Nguyen Van Hien officially elevated it to a parish under the care of the Saigon Archdiocese. The original, simple church was a sign of the community's dedication to establishing a new spiritual home. Over the following decades, figures like Father Anton Trinh Ngoc Van initiated land expansion, and the parish population grew significantly. The physical features of the complex are centralized around its vast sanctuary, built on the foundation of a prior structure. Located at 1 Hoang Van Hoe in the Tan Phu district (a key geographical detail corresponding to approximately 10.80 N, 106.63 E), the current church was constructed between 2005 and 2007, culminating in its consecration on December 22, 2007, under Father Phe-ro Nguyen Quoc Tuy. Its large-scale architecture features a distinctive, balanced form with a broad, square interior designed to accommodate its sizeable congregation, which is reported to number around 10,000 parishioners. Today, Giao Xu Tan Thai Son remains an extremely large and active parish within the Tan Son Nhi Deanery, continuing its legacy as a cultural and faith anchor that provides extensive spiritual and community support to a dynamic and rapidly developing urban residential zone.

name: Tan Phu Parish
description: Giao Xu Tan Phu is a monumental Catholic Parish Complex from the Mid-20th Century, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the South Vietnamese Catholic Resettlement Culture. This essential center is globally renowned for its history as a Community Resettlement Project, its distinctive Modernist-Inspired Church Architecture, its vast Community Outreach Programs, and its role as a Major Spiritual Center in Ho Chi Minh City. The parish traces its origins to 1963 when Archbishop Paul Nguyen Van Binh commissioned its establishment on two hectares of challenging, low-lying land in what was then Gia Dinh Province. The land, provided by local authorities, was intended as a dedicated settlement area, complete with a place of worship, school, and medical facilities, primarily for Catholic families who had migrated from Northern Vietnam. The first pastor, Father Domin Dinh Xuan Hai, oversaw the initial construction of a temporary church made of bamboo and leaves for the community's initial 83 families. The initial structure was later replaced by a more stable concrete church in 1967. The parish experienced significant growth, necessitating the construction of a much larger and more modern sanctuary, which was inaugurated in 1997 under Father Domin Vu Nguyen Thieu. This current church, located at 90 Nguyen Hau Street, features a striking 18-meter-high facade composed of seven vertical blocks. The highest section is uniquely designed to resemble a pair of hands embracing the Cross, a powerful symbol of divine love and protection. The extensive campus is a spacious compound capable of hosting up to 2000 worshipers and includes a circuit of the 14 Stations of the Cross. Giao Xu Tan Phu continues its long legacy as one of the most vibrant and largest parishes in the Archdiocese of Saigon, remaining a central spiritual and cultural anchor that fosters community cohesion and faith development.

name: Phu Trung Parish
description: Giao Xu Phu Trung is a monumental Catholic Parish and Spiritual Center from the Mid-to-Late 20th Century, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Vietnamese Catholic Community in Saigon. This essential complex is globally renowned for its history as a Refugee Community Establishment, its role as a vibrant Community Hub, its distinctive Contemporary Architectural Features, and its dedicated service as a Major Spiritual Center in Tan Binh District. The parish traces its origins to the aftermath of the 1968 Tet Offensive, when approximately 300 Catholic faithful displaced by the war settled in the Bay Hien area, initially belonging to Tan Viet Parish. It was officially founded by Archbishop Paul Nguyen Van Binh on August 15, 1974, with Father Phanxico Assisi Le Quang Dang as its first pastor, to provide a dedicated place of worship and social cohesion for the growing number of parishioners. The church complex is located at 1434 Lac Long Quan Street, HCMC, spanning a large campus of approximately 8000 square meters. Key physical features include the main modern sanctuary, a 45-meter-tall bell tower (Thap Chuong), a three-story activity house, and a rectory of 440 square meters. The grounds are adorned with a statue of the Virgin Mary, a statue of St. Francis Xavier (the patron saint), and the 14 Stations of the Cross. Giao Xu Phu Trung currently operates as an active, thriving parish within the Tan Son Nhi Deanery of the Archdiocese of Saigon, maintaining its enduring legacy as a spiritual and social anchor for local families through daily masses, community programs, and religious devotion.

name: Phu Tho Hoa Parish
description: Giao Xu Phu Tho Hoa is a monumental Catholic Parish and Religious Center from the Mid-20th Century, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Vietnamese Catholic Culture in Ho Chi Minh City. This essential complex is globally renowned for its profound Spiritual Formation activities, its role as a vital Community Hub, its dedicated Post-war Establishment, and its continued devotion under the patronage of Christ the King. The parish was established in two main phases between 1965 and 1974, arising from the need to provide a dedicated place of worship and spiritual guidance for the rapidly growing Catholic population in the area of what is now Tan Phu District. Successive priests have guided its development, notably undertaking renovations and expansions to better serve the faithful, such as the construction of the rectory's office and perimeter fencing. The church is located at 39 Luong Truc Dam, Hiep Tan Ward, Tan Phu District, Ho Chi Minh City, with an approximate coordinate of 10.79 degrees North latitude and 106.63 degrees East longitude. The complex encompasses a main sanctuary (Thanh Duong), the rectory (Nha Xu), and an area dedicated to community services and spiritual devotion. Recent architectural additions, including the construction of a Dai Duc Me (Our Lady’s Shrine) and Nha Hai Cot (Columbarium), demonstrate its ongoing evolution. Giao Xu Phu Tho Hoa currently operates as an active, vibrant parish within the Tan Son Nhi Deanery of the Archdiocese of Saigon, maintaining an enduring legacy as a spiritual anchor for thousands of local families through regular masses, educational programs, and community outreach.

name: Dac Lo Parish
description: Giao Xu Dac Lo is a monumental Religious and Educational Center from the Mid-20th Century, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Vietnamese Catholic and Jesuit Missionary Culture. This revered complex is globally renowned for its profound Religious Significance, its foundational role as a Student Educational Hub, its connection to the Jesuit Order's Apostolic Work, and its enduring presence as a center for Spiritual Formation. The parish's origins trace back to the establishment of the Jesuit Fathers, or Dong Ten, in Sai Gon in the late 1950s, with a primary purpose to engage in pastoral and apostolic work with students and intellectuals. The parish was officially founded in 1975 by Archbishop Paul Nguyen Van Binh, but its ministry began earlier, with the construction of the Cu Xa Sinh Vien Dac Lo, a student residence, completed in 1962 with 30 rooms to house 60 male students, embodying the order's educational mission. The complex, situated in the Tan Binh District of Ho Chi Minh City (approximately 10.8 N, 106.65 E, estimated), features a large chapel and associated educational facilities. While specific architectural details on materials and size are limited, the buildings reflect the functional, contemporary style common to educational and religious constructions of the period. Following 1975, parts of the complex were utilized by state-run entities like the Tuoi Tre newspaper and a printing factory, though some property was returned to the Jesuit Order in 2006. Today, Giao Xu Dac Lo remains a vibrant, active parish and the official Dac Lo Center of the Vietnamese Jesuits, continuing its legacy of spiritual and intellectual formation for the greater Catholic community.

name: Hanh Phu Communal House
description: Dinh Hanh Phu is a monumental Communal Temple and Resistance Landmark from the Late 19th Century to the Mid-20th Century, serving as an iconic surviving structure of the Southern Vietnamese Communal and Resistance Culture. This revered site is globally renowned for its critical role as a Secret Supply Depot during the Anti-French Resistance, its status as a recognized District-level Heritage Site, and its enduring function as a hub of Local Cultural and Spiritual Heritage. Historically, the temple's establishment followed the consolidation of the Hanh Phu village, although its precise founding date remains undocumented. Its original purpose was, and remains, to serve as the spiritual and administrative center for the local community, honoring the village's tutelary god and celebrated figures. The temple's most significant historical contribution began in November 1945, when it was selected by the Resistance Committee of Gia Dinh province to serve as a crucial logistics center. It became a covert storehouse where boats delivered essential supplies like food and medicine to support anti-French cadres and soldiers operating in the surrounding region. The physical features of the Dinh follow the traditional Southern Vietnamese temple architecture, typically featuring multiple halls (Tien Dien and Chanh Dien) constructed from durable wood and tile, embodying a humble yet resilient design, and is situated within the An Phu Dong area of District 12 (approx. 10.85 N, 106.67 E, estimated). Today, Dinh Hanh Phu is preserved as a historical and cultural relic, upholding the legacy of community unity and its pivotal contribution to the nation's struggle for independence, drawing visitors seeking to connect with the local history.

name: Nguyen Anh Thu Temple
description: Den tho Nguyen Anh Thu is a monumental Commemoration Temple and Historical Resistance Base from the Late 19th Century, serving as an iconic surviving structure of the Southern Vietnamese Anti-Colonial Tradition. This site is globally renowned for its crucial role as a Secret Resistance Base during the Anti-American War, its status as a City-level Historical Monument, and its enduring function as a Commemoration Shrine for a national hero. The temple's origins trace back to the mid-19th century, honoring Nguyen Anh Thu, a courageous leader who spearheaded the resistance movement against French occupation in the area of Tan Thoi Nhat. Following his life of activism, local people established the shrine around 1890 to remember his contributions to the cause of national independence. Beyond its initial purpose as a place of worship and tribute, the temple later became a critical secret liaison and meeting point for soldiers and activists fighting during the later Anti-American Resistance War, enduring numerous sweeps by enemy forces. While detailed blueprints are not widely documented, the site is a traditional Vietnamese-style shrine constructed with simple, durable local materials, and is located at approximately 10.83 degrees North, 106.61 degrees West, in Tan Thoi Nhat Ward, District 12, Ho Chi Minh City. In 2011, the site was officially recognized as a City-level Historical Monument by the Ho Chi Minh City People's Committee (Decision 3948/QD-UBND). Today, it stands as a testament to the resilient spirit of the Vietnamese people, actively maintained as a historical landmark that preserves the memory of local resistance efforts.

name: An Quang Pagoda
description: An Quang Pagoda is a monumental Buddhist Temple and Educational Center from the Post-War Period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Southern Vietnamese Buddhist Tradition. This complex is globally renowned for its role as the Historical Headquarters of the Unified Buddhist Church of Vietnam, its deep-seated connection to Political and Social Activism during the 1960s, and its continuous function as a central Buddhist Educational Center. The pagoda originated in 1948 as Ung Quang Tu, a small, dried-leaf roof hermitage spanning 500 square meters, founded by the Buddhist monk Thich Thien Tri as a school for young monks. In 1950, the management was transferred to monk Thich Thien Hoa, who supervised the building of the Main Hall. The pagoda was officially renamed An Quang and became the headquarters of the Nam Viet Buddhist School. The complex rapidly expanded in the mid-1950s with the addition of a library, publishing house, and printing press. From 1965 to 1980, the pagoda was the headquarters of the Unified Buddhist Church of Vietnam, and it played a crucial role as a gathering place for activists during the 1963 Buddhist struggle. The design, executed by the talented Nguyen Huu Thien, blends elements from Vietnamese, Indian, Chinese, and Japanese architectures, notably drawing inspiration from Tu Dam Pagoda in Hue. Its architectural features include green-tiled, curved roofs decorated with red dragon ornaments and a prominent red dharma wheel. A seven-story, square stupa, built in 2009, dominates the grounds. Located at 243 Su Van Hanh Street, District 10, the pagoda today serves as the Headquarters of the Ho Chi Minh City Buddhist Sangha and remains a vital center for Dharma propagation and education, maintaining its legacy as a principal pillar of Vietnamese Buddhism.

name: Tu Nghiem Pagoda
description: Chua Tu Nghiem is a monumental Buddhist Nunnery and Educational Center from the Post-War Period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Northern Vietnamese Buddhist Nunnery Tradition. This complex is globally renowned for its role as the Historical Headquarters of the Northern Buddhist Nuns, its association with Political and Social Activism, and its enduring status as a highly disciplined Monastic School for women. The pagoda originated as a simple thatched hermitage founded by the Venerable Thich Dat Tu. In 1957, leadership was transferred to the nuns (Ni), and the structure was officially rebuilt from 1959 to 1962. From 1960 to 1975, it functioned as the official Southern headquarters for the Northern Buddhist Nunnery, under the direction of Abbess TN. Nhu Thanh. The temple was a focal point during the 1963 Buddhist struggle against the Ngo Dinh Diem regime, with its nuns actively participating in protests. It is also historically linked to the 1967 self-immolation of Buddhist student activist Nhat Chi Mai, becoming a symbol of anti-war sentiment and student resistance. Although initially a simple thatched structure, the current form reflects the traditional Bac Tong (Northern Buddhist) architectural style, rebuilt with permanent materials. Its physical location at 415-417 Ba Hat, District 10, positions it in a bustling labor district, reflecting its historical connection to the working class. It primarily functions as a "Noi Vien," or internal academy, prioritizing the monastic life and strict adherence to the Vinaya (monastic code). Today, Chua Tu Nghiem remains a thriving spiritual and educational institution, overseen by Abbess TN. Nhu Hoa, with approximately 70 nuns in residence. It upholds a reputation for rigorous study and practice, contributing to Buddhist education, outreach (Dharma propagation), and community development, thereby ensuring its continuous legacy in the religious and social landscape of Ho Chi Minh City.

name: Long Hoa Pagoda (District 8)
description: Chua Long Hoa (District 8) is a monumental Buddhist Temple and Spiritual Center from the Post-War Period, serving as a primary cultural structure of the Hoa Buddhist Tradition in Southern Vietnam. The pagoda is renowned for its distinctly Chinese Classical Architecture, its importance as the historical headquarters of the Hoa Buddhist Association, its significant Social Welfare Contributions, and its large collection of three thousand Medicine Buddha statues. The temple's origins trace back to 1958, when it was founded on a 6,000 square meter plot by the venerable Thich Sieu Tran, who was also the Chairman of the Hoa Buddhist Association from 1973 to 1975. Initially a simple monastery, its primary purpose was to serve as a religious and cultural anchor for the Chinese-Vietnamese Buddhist community in the Cho Lon area. The site fell into disuse for a period after 1976 but was subsequently revitalized and developed from 1996 by the Venerable Hue Cong through multiple reconstructions. The architecture is distinctly marked by the ornate, multi-tiered style of classical Chinese temples, featuring a grand triple-gate entrance, a two-story Main Hall (Dai Hung Bao Dien) which houses a 3-meter-tall Shakyamuni Buddha statue, and a separate Sutra Storage Pavilion (Tang Kinh Giac). A notable feature is the Avalokitesvara Pavilion (Quan Am Cac) constructed over a pond, adjacent to a 25-meter-long wall relief depicting 18 dragons. Located at 360A Ben Binh Dong, Ward 15, District 8, the temple's location along the Lo Gom canal connects it to the historical river trade routes of Ho Chi Minh City. Chua Long Hoa remains an active and impressive center for the Northern Buddhist school. Its enduring legacy is one of cultural preservation and community service, continually drawing both local devotees and spiritual tourism through initiatives such as specialized river tours, cementing its status as an important religious and cultural landmark.

name: An Phu Pagoda (Mien Sanh Pagoda)
description: The Chua An Phu (Mieng Sanh Pagoda) is a monumental Buddhist Temple and Architectural Art Relic from the Mid-19th Century, serving as a unique and iconic structure of Southern Vietnamese Buddhist Heritage and Folk Art. This site is globally renowned for its Unique Ceramic Mosaic Architecture, holding a Vietnamese Record for the extensive use of Recycled Shards, its function as a Major Religious Center for the Northern Buddhist Tradition, and its possession of Giant Ceremonial Candles. The pagoda's history dates back to 1847, when it was founded by Venerable Thich Thanh Duc, initially following a simple Nam Bo (Southern) style. The temple's most significant transformation began in 1961 under Venerable Thich Tu Bach, initiating decades of labor to reinforce and decorate the structure. The purpose of the extensive ceramic work was not just aesthetic, but a powerful metaphor for renewal and rebirth, transforming discarded waste into enduring art, a core value within the Buddhist teachings. Situated on a 1,500 square meter campus at 24 Chanh Hung Street, District 8, the temple is built in the Co Lau (Ancient Pavilion) architectural style. Its defining feature is the intricate mosaic work, created using over 30 tons of broken ceramic pieces from cups, bowls, and plates, meticulously applied across a surface area of approximately 3,886 square meters. This intricate exterior contrasts with the more traditional layouts of its sanctuaries, which also house immense ceremonial candles. Chua An Phu continues to serve as an active spiritual center and pilgrimage site, known to follow the Bac Tong (Northern) Buddhist tradition. It was officially recognized in 2007 by the Vietnam Record Book Center as the pagoda with the most ceramic shard mosaic work in the country. The temple is an enduring cultural landmark in Ho Chi Minh City, symbolizing a successful convergence of religious devotion, folk craftsmanship, and ecological awareness.

name: Giac Hai Pagoda (District 6)
description: The Chua Giac Hai is a monumental Buddhist Temple and Architectural Art Relic from the Late 19th Century to Early 20th Century period, serving as one of the most iconic surviving structures of Southern Vietnamese Buddhist Heritage. Its current architecture, which took shape around 1920, stands as a valuable resource for studying the evolution of Buddhism in the Nam Bo region. This site is globally renowned for its unique Architectural Style, its role as a Center for Buddhist Education, its preservation of Ancient Wooden Statues, and its connection to the surrounding traditional Buddha Statue Craft Village. The pagoda's origins trace back to 1887 when Mrs. Tran Thi Lieu initiated the construction of a small temple named Giac Son in Tan Hoa Dong village. She subsequently offered it to Venerable Hoang An, who appointed his disciple, Venerable Tu Phong, as the abbot and formally renamed the site Giac Hai. Venerable Tu Phong became a distinguished lecturer of Southern Vietnamese Buddhism, increasing the pagoda's importance as a religious and educational hub. The Main Hall, or Chinh Dien, exhibits a distinctive, sturdy, rectangular design with a high ceiling, differentiating it from traditional Northern-school Vietnamese pagodas. The interior is divided into three sections by ten circular cement columns, lavishly decorated with golden coiled dragon reliefs. The complex, located at 1017/3 Hong Bang Street, retains valuable relics, including an ancient set of Ngu Hien (Five Sages) wooden statues, and is notable for the presence of four protective stupas within its grounds. Today, Chua Giac Hai is officially recognized as a City-level Architectural Art Relic by the Ho Chi Minh City People's Committee since 2015. It maintains its status as an active place of worship and a symbol of local religious continuity, standing adjacent to a historic neighborhood renowned for crafting Buddhist statuary.

name: Hoa Binh Communal House, Hoa Binh Park
description: The Hoa Binh Pavilion is a monumental International Friendship Monument from the Post-War Republic Period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the South Vietnamese and Korean cultural exchange. This distinctive blue pavilion is globally renowned for its unique Korean Palgagjeong Architecture, its tangible representation of International Friendship, its value as an Urban Landmark, and its historical roots in the region's Buddhist community. The origins of the pavilion date back to 1972. It was designed and constructed by the Korean Buddhist monk and artist Lee Man-bong, along with a team of five others, with the explicit purpose of serving as a memorial to symbolize the bond of friendship between the Republic of Vietnam and Korea during a turbulent era. The groundbreaking ceremony took place on February 8, 1972, and the structure was officially inaugurated on July 27, 1972, within what was then known as Hung Vuong Park. The park itself was subsequently renamed Hoa Binh Park (Peace Park) in honor of the monument's name and symbolic meaning, a name that has been preserved to the present day. Architecturally, the pavilion is a typical example of a Bat Giac Dinh, or Palgagjeong, which translates to Octagonal Pavilion, a traditional Korean motif often utilized in memorial and commemorative structures. Its striking deep blue color and the intricate design of the multi-tiered roof structure are its most notable physical features, distinguishing it sharply from the surrounding Vietnamese and French colonial architecture. The pavilion is centrally located within the park in District 5, at an approximate position of 10.7584 degrees North latitude and 106.6669 degrees East longitude. The Hoa Binh Pavilion remains a familiar and actively preserved cultural and historical marker in the Saigon-Cholon area, continually reminding locals and visitors of the complex international and cultural history of the city.

name: Hue Nghiem Pagoda
description: Hue Nghiem Pagoda is a monumental Buddhist Sanctuary from the Early 18th Century, serving as one of the most iconic surviving structures of the Southern Vietnamese Buddhist tradition. This tranquil complex is globally renowned for its long-standing Religious Significance, its City-level Architectural Relic status, its enduring role as a Spiritual Oasis, and its repository of Traditional Art, reflecting centuries of devotion. The pagoda's original foundation is attributed to Zen Master Thiet Thuy – Tanh Tuong, with historical records dating its establishment to approximately 1721, placing it among the oldest temples in Ho Chi Minh City. Initially constructed in a lowland area, the temple was later relocated and rebuilt on land donated by Ms. Nguyen Thi Hien in the late 18th or early 19th century. Its foundational purpose was to serve as a center for Mahayana Buddhist worship, spiritual practice, and the propagation of the faith, taking its name from the Avatamsaka Sutra (Kinh Hoa Nghiem). The physical structure has undergone multiple major restorations, including a significant period in the late 19th century and subsequent renovations in 1960, 1969, 1990, and 2003, which have altered its architectural profile to accommodate its growth. The current expansive campus, located on Dang Van Bi street in Thu Duc City, features an array of structures, including ancient stupas and a main hall adorned with intricate carvings and elaborate decorative elements that exemplify the high craftsmanship of its builders. The design fosters an atmosphere of profound serenity and spiritual harmony. Chùa Huệ Nghiêm remains a vital and actively preserved cultural and religious landmark. It stands as a living testament to the local community's unwavering faith, continuing its legacy by hosting regular Buddhist rituals, ceremonies, and meditation practices, thereby inspiring and uplifting countless visitors and practitioners.

name: Hai Thuong Lan Ong ancient house area
description:
The Hai Thuong Lan Ong Ancient Quarter is a distinguished Historic Shophouse Enclave from the Late 19th Century, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Hoa Commercial Civilization in the historic Cholon district. This precinct is locally renowned for its status as a specialized Traditional Medicine Hub, its distinct Sino-French Architectural Fusion, and its enduring Living Heritage, preserving the sensory and physical landscape of colonial-era trade. Historically, the street was originally established as Rue des Marins (Sailors' Street) and rapidly evolved into the epicenter of the Oriental medicine trade, developed by wealthy Chinese merchants from Fujian and Guangdong who built these shophouses to serve simultaneously as wholesale apothecaries, warehouses, and multi-generational family residences.

Architecturally, the quarter features a continuous row of traditional "tube houses" that blend utilitarian merchant layouts with decorative aesthetics, showcasing French-style shuttered windows and wrought-iron balustrades alongside Chinese ceramic roof tiles and intricate stucco reliefs. Located at the specific coordinates of 10.7535 N Latitude and 106.6645 E Longitude, the designated heritage zone spans the section between Luong Nhu Hoc and Trieu Quang Phuc streets, creating a cohesive visual corridor that has remained largely intact for over a century. Today, the area is officially recognized and protected by the District 5 administration as the city's "Traditional Medicine Street" (Pho Dong Y), where the scent of herbs still permeates the air, standing as a vibrant testament to the economic resilience and cultural continuity of the Chinese-Vietnamese community in Ho Chi Minh City.

name: Vinh Hoi Communal House
description: Dinh Vinh Hoi is a monumental Traditional Communal House from the Early 19th Century, serving as one of the most iconic surviving structures of the Southern Vietnamese Culture. The complex, established by the local community of the former Gia Dinh province, embodies the spiritual and communal heart of its residents. This sacred site is globally renowned as a City-level Architectural-Art Relic, a crucial Historical Landmark, and a repository of Traditional Art, representing a preserved link to the old Gia Dinh settlement. The communal house was constructed between 1818 and 1836, following the establishment of the Vinh Hoi village in the Tan Binh prefecture of Gia Dinh province. Its primary and enduring purpose was to worship the village's tutelary deity, the Thanh Hoang Bon Can, and to venerate local ancestors and distinguished contributors to the community. The Dinh notably holds a royal charter of recognition (sac phong) bestowed by King Tu Duc in 1895, confirming its official status within the Nguyen Dynasty's religious hierarchy. The surrounding area was also a historic focal point during the fierce resistance against the 1859 French-Spanish attack on Gia Dinh Citadel. The Dinh occupies a grounds area of nearly 700 square meters. The structure originally featured a Vo Ca (ceremonial hall), which has since been lost, and the main structure which houses the Chinh Dien (main hall) and Nghia Tu (ancestral house). These remaining sections are built in the traditional five-bay style using wooden columns, beams, and rafters, all beneath a tiled roof. The interior is a showcase of high-quality Southern Vietnamese woodcarving art, featuring intricate decorative motifs such as 'phung hoang trieu nguyet' (phoenixes paying homage to the moon) and 'luong long tranh chau' (two dragons vying for a pearl). Furthermore, the Dinh preserves valuable bronze artifacts, notably two ornate incense burners that are exemplary pieces of late 19th-century Saigon-Gia Dinh casting. Its current, precise location is at 46 Dinh Hoa Street, Ward 13, District 8, Ho Chi Minh City. Dinh Vinh Hoi was officially recognized as an Architectural-Art Relic in 1989. It continues to be a vibrant center for traditional beliefs and is actively preserved, maintaining its legacy as a cultural anchor for the modern community in Ho Chi Minh City.

name: Dinh Khanh Hoi
description: Dinh Khanh Hoi is a monumental Traditional Communal House from the Early 20th Century, serving as one of the most iconic surviving structures of the Southern Vietnamese Culture. This communal house is globally renowned as an Architectural-Art Relic, a crucial Historical Landmark, and a center for Ancestral Worship, representing the spiritual heart of the Gia Dinh community. Its origins trace back to the former Khanh Hoi village, which was tragically burned down by the French forces in February 1858 during the initial conquest of Gia Dinh, a pivotal moment in Vietnamese history. The Dinh was officially reconstructed at its current site in 1935, preserving the religious and communal purpose of the original, which was to worship the village’s tutelary deity (Thanh Hoang Bon Can) and revered ancestors. Architecturally, the structure adheres to the traditional chu cong (工-shaped) layout, consisting of the Dai Bai (Great Hall), Trung Tu (Central Sanctuary), and Hau Cung (Rear Palace). It features intricate wood carpentry with a keo cau tru bang structural system and highly skilled traditional carvings on its internal components, reflecting the craftsmanship of the period. The Dinh is located approximately at 10.76 degrees North and 106.71 degrees East, anchoring the historic Khanh Hoi ward. It continues to operate as an essential spiritual site, hosting vibrant traditional festivals. It was officially recognized as a City-level Architectural and Art Relic in 2006 by Ho Chi Minh City authorities, ensuring its protection and legacy as a repository of local culture and history.

name: Southern Women's Museum
description: The Southern Women's Museum is a monumental Museum and Cultural Heritage Site from the Post-War Contemporary period, serving as a vital archive of modern Southern Vietnamese Culture. It is a key institution for Historical Education, Revolutionary History, Ethnic Costume Preservation, and Gender Empowerment, honoring the significant contributions of women to national defense and development. Established on April 29, 1985, by the Research Group for the History of Southern Women, the museum was created to preserve and educate future generations on the patriotism and revolutionary traditions of women in the South. The official inauguration took place on May 18, 1990, after construction began in 1986. Its core mission is to showcase the history of revolutionary struggle and the cultural heritage of Southern women through extensive collections. The institution is centrally located at 200–202 Vo Thi Sau Street, District 3, Ho Chi Minh City. The multi-story building features approximately 3,699 square meters of floor space dedicated to exhibits across 27 permanent themed displays and houses over 700 square meters for collection storage. The collections are organized into 24 subject groups, including rare artifacts, documents, and traditional costumes of various ethnic groups in the Southern region. Today, the museum remains a significant destination, attracting around 100,000 domestic and international visitors yearly. Its legacy is its continuous effort to promote understanding of women's historical roles, cultural diversity, and ongoing development, maintaining cooperative programs with international memory centers and museums.

name: War Remnants Museum
description: The War Remnants Museum is a monumental Museum and Historical Archive from the Post-War/Contemporary History period, serving as one of the most iconic structures of Modern Vietnamese History. This center is globally renowned as a Global Peace Destination, a critical site for War Crime Documentation, Historical Education, and Cultural Preservation. Established on September 4, 1975, by the Ho Chi Minh City government, it was originally named the "Exhibition House for US and Puppet Crimes," reflecting its initial purpose to document the consequences of the Vietnam War. Its name was later changed to the War Remnants Museum in 1995 following the normalization of diplomatic relations with the United States, shifting its mission to educating the public on anti-war awareness, peace, and international friendship. Located at 28 Vo Van Tan Street, Ho Chi Minh City, with coordinates approximately 10.779475 North and 106.692132 East, the facility features a modern, multi-story main building complemented by an extensive outdoor exhibition area spanning over 3,000 square meters. The grounds display large-scale military equipment, including US helicopters, tanks, and a "Daisy Cutter" bomb, while the indoor galleries feature graphic photography, artifacts related to Agent Orange's long-term effects, and a haunting replica of the "tiger cages" prison system. Today, the museum is a member of the International Council of Museums (ICOM) and the Museum for World Peace System, attracting nearly one million visitors annually. Its enduring legacy is its role as a powerful, emotional, and educational pilgrimage site dedicated to promoting peace, remembrance, and solidarity among nations.

name: Xuan Hoa Communal House
description: The Xuan Hoa Communal House is a monumental Religious Sanctuary and Communal House from the Early 19th-Century period, serving as one of the most iconic surviving structures of the Traditional Vietnamese Village Culture in the central region. This sacred site is widely recognized as a Provincial-Level Historical Relic, a prime example of Traditional Hue Architecture, a vital Communal Worship Center, and an enduring symbol of Cultural Preservation, maintaining local typical values over two centuries. Historically, the Dinh Xuan Hoa was originally established by the local residents of the Kim Long area, situated near the Perfume River (Huong River), approximately two hundred years ago. Its primary purpose was to serve as the spiritual and administrative heart of the community, a place of worship dedicated to the Village Guardian Spirit (Thanh Hoang) and a venue for traditional village rituals, reflecting the deep-rooted customs of the region. The architectural style is characteristic of the Nguyen Dynasty era in Hue, featuring a simple, nature-friendly design with a focus on balanced details and connection to the surrounding environment, a construction that has been preserved by the collective efforts of the villagers for its entire existence. The physical location is documented at 86 Nguyen Phuc Nguyen Street, in the Kim Long ward of Hue City, situated within the Thua Thien Hue province. Today, the Xuan Hoa Communal House continues its legacy as an active cultural and religious center. Its official status was cemented when it was recognized as a provincial-level historical-cultural relic by the Thua Thien Hue Provincial People's Committee on March 17, 2011. This designation ensures its continued protection and highlights its enduring role in preserving the spiritual and historical identity of the local community.

name: Temple of Ba Thien Hau Thanh Mau
description: Thien Hau Temple, officially the Tue Thanh Guildhall, is a monumental Religious Sanctuary and Guildhall from the Late 18th-Century/Colonial Era, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Cantonese Chinese Civilization in Southern Vietnam. This sacred site is globally renowned as the oldest Chinese temple in Saigon, an Architectural Fusion Masterpiece, a Spiritual Anchor, and a Cultural Melting Pot, vital to the religious life of the community. Historically, the temple was first erected around 1760 by the Cantonese (Guangzhou) community who settled in the Cholon district, establishing it as both a communal meeting hall (Hoi Quan) and a central place of worship for Mazu, the Goddess of the Sea, who safeguarded them on their voyage across the ocean. Its construction was an act of preserving cultural and spiritual identity for the seafaring migrants. The temple's architecture follows a traditional Chinese "Khau" or "Quoc" (口 or 國) shaped layout, consisting of four interconnected house sections surrounding a courtyard (thien tinh). The structure is distinguished by its intricate wooden framework and a roof lavishly decorated with delicate, glazed porcelain figurines and pottery sculptures, many dating back to 1908, representing themes from Chinese legends. The compound occupies a total area of over 1,200 square meters. The precise coordinates of this enduring structure are 10°45′10.48″ North, 106°39′40.22″ East. Today, the Thien Hau Temple remains a National Architectural Relic and a highly active religious center in Ho Chi Minh City's District 5. It continues to be a pilgrimage site for both ethnic Chinese and Vietnamese people, hosting one of the most significant annual festivals in the city on the 23rd day of the third lunar month to celebrate Mazu’s birthday, thus securing its legacy as an irreplaceable cultural heritage landmark.

name: Phu Thanh Communal House (District 3)
description: Đình Phú Thạnh là một di tích kiến trúc cấp thành phố tại Quận 3. Đình được xây dựng vào đầu thế kỷ 19, vẫn còn lưu giữ sắc phong từ triều Nguyễn ban vào năm 1853. Đây là một trong những ngôi đình cổ nhất của khu vực, thờ Thành Hoàng Bổn Cảnh và các vị Tiền hiền, Hậu hiền.

name: Water tower (District 3)
description: The Thuy Dai (District 3) is a monumental Water Engineering Structure from the French Colonial Period, serving as the most iconic surviving structure of the Saigon-Indochinese Engineering Heritage. This historical site is globally renowned for its status as the Oldest Existing Water Tower in Saigon, its massive load-bearing Architectural Form, its role as a Critical Historical Water Supply System, and its current preservation as an official City-level Architectural Relic. Built by the French in 1886, the Thuy Dai was constructed with the original purpose of forming a key part of the water distribution system for the rapidly expanding urban areas of Saigon, Gia Dinh, and Cho Lon. It operated effectively by pumping water from a central well into its elevated tanks to create the necessary hydrostatic pressure for delivery to nearby households.
